metadata.section_title: Suitability requirements for a partner or child of a Graduate Trainee

chunks.text:
### Suitability requirements for a partner or child of a Graduate Trainee

GTR 15.1. The applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.

1.   GTR 15.2. If applying for permission to stay the applicant must not be: 
    1.   (a) in breach of immigration laws, except that where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, that period of overstaying will be disregarded; or
    2.   (b) on immigration bail.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to partners and children of Graduate Trainees. They must be suitable, not breach immigration laws (unless overstaying falls under specific exceptions), and not be on immigration bail to qualify for permission to stay.

metadata.section_title: Entry requirement for a partner or child of a Graduate Trainee

chunks.text:
### Entry requirement for a partner or child of a Graduate Trainee

GTR 16.1. A person seeking to come to the UK as a partner or child must apply for and obtain entry clearance as a partner or child of a Graduate Trainee before they arrive in the UK.

GTR 16.2. A person applying for entry clearance as the partner or child of a Graduate Trainee must, if Appendix Tuberculosis applies, provide a valid medical certificate confirming that they have undergone screening for active pulmonary tuberculosis and that this tuberculosis is not present in them.
chunks.summary: Partners or children of Graduate Trainees must apply for and obtain entry clearance before arriving in the UK. If applicable, they must provide a medical certificate confirming tuberculosis screening, unless exempt.

metadata.section_title: Relationship requirement for a partner of a Graduate Trainee

chunks.text:
### Relationship requirement for a partner of a Graduate Trainee

1.   GTR 17.1. The applicant must be the partner of a person (P) where one of the following applies: 
    1.   (a) P has permission as a Graduate Trainee; or
    2.   (b) P is, at the same time, applying for (and is granted) entry clearance or permission as a Graduate Trainee.

GTR 17.2. The requirements of Appendix Relationship with Partner must be met.

GTR 17.3. DELETED

GTR 17.4. DELETED
chunks.summary: This provision applies to partners of Graduate Trainees. They must demonstrate a genuine relationship with a person granted or applying for Graduate Trainee permission, meeting the requirements of the Appendix on Relationships with Partners. There are no additional conditions beyond these relationship criteria.

metadata.section_title: Requirements for a dependent child of a Graduate Trainee

chunks.text:
### Requirements for a dependent child of a Graduate Trainee

1.   GTR 20A.1. The applicant must meet the following requirements for a dependent child in Appendix Children: 
    1.   (a) relationship requirement: entry clearance and permission to stay; and
    2.   (b) care requirement; and
    3.   (c) age and independent life requirement.
chunks.summary: Dependent children of Graduate Trainees must meet relationship, care, and age/independent living requirements outlined in Appendix Children to qualify for entry clearance and permission to stay, with specific conditions concerning their relationship, care arrangements, and age limits.

metadata.section_title: Financial requirement for a partner or child of a Graduate Trainee

chunks.text:
### Financial requirement for a partner or child of a Graduate Trainee

GTR 21.1. If the applicant is applying for permission to stay and has been living in the UK with permission for 12 months or longer on the date of application, they will meet the financial requirement and do not need to show funds.

1.   GTR 21.2. If the applicant is applying for entry clearance, or is applying for permission to stay and has not been in the UK for 12 months on the date of application, either: 
    1.   (a) funds of at least the amount required in GTR 21.3 must be held collectively by one or more of the following: 
        1.   (i) the applicant; and
        2.   (ii) the Graduate Trainee (P); and
        3.   (iii) if the applicant is applying as a child, their parent who is lawfully present in the UK or being granted entry clearance, or permission to stay at the same time as the applicant; or

    2.   (b) the sponsor of P must confirm on the Certificate of Sponsorship that they will, if necessary, maintain and accommodate the partner and/or any child as well as P, up to the end of the first month of each of their permission, up to at least the amounts in GTR 21.3.

2.   GTR 21.3. The required funds are: 
    1.   (a) £285 for a partner in the UK or applying for entry clearance; and
    2.   (b) £315 for the first child in the UK or applying for entry clearance; and
    3.   (c) £200 for any other child in the UK or applying for entry clearance.

GTR 21.4. If GTR 21.2.(a) applies, the funds held must be held in addition to any funds required for the Graduate Trainee to meet the financial requirement and the funds required for any dependants in the UK or applying at the same time.

GTR 21.5. If GTR 21.2.(a) applies, the funds must have been held for a 28-day period and as specified in Appendix Finance.
chunks.summary: Applicants who have been in the UK for 12 months or more do not need to show funds when applying for a partner or child. If not, they must evidence funds of at least £285 for a partner or £315 for a child, or have the sponsor confirm they can support them, unless the applicant has been in the UK for over a year.

### Financial requirement for a partner or child of a Graduate Trainee

GTR 21.1. If the applicant is applying for permission to stay and has been living in the UK with permission for 12 months or longer on the date of application, they will meet the financial requirement and do not need to show funds.

1.   GTR 21.2. If the applicant is applying for entry clearance, or is applying for permission to stay and has not been in the UK for 12 months on the date of application, either:

        1.   (i) the applicant; and

2.   GTR 21.3. The required funds are: 
    1.   (a) £285 for a partner in the UK or applying for entry clearance; and
    2.   (b) £315 for the first child in the UK or applying for entry clearance; and
    3.   (c) £200 for any other child in the UK or applying for entry clearance.

GTR 21.4. If GTR 21.2.(a) applies, the funds held must be held in addition to any funds required for the Graduate Trainee to meet the financial requirement and the funds required for any dependants in the UK or applying at the same time.

GTR 21.5. If GTR 21.2.(a) applies, the funds must have been held for a 28-day period and as specified in Appendix Finance.

metadata.section_title: Decision on an application as a partner or child of a Graduate Trainee

chunks.text:
### Decision on an application as a partner or child of a Graduate Trainee

GTR 22.1. If the decision maker is satisfied that all the suitability and eligibility requirements are met for a partner or child of a Graduate Trainee the application will be granted, otherwise the application will be refused.

GTR 22.2. If the application is refused the person can apply for an Administrative Review under Appendix AR: Administrative Review.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to partners or children of Graduate Trainees. The decision maker grants the application if suitability and eligibility criteria are met; otherwise, it is refused, with a right to seek Administrative Review.

GTR 22.1. If the decision maker is satisfied that all the suitability and eligibility requirements are met for a partner or child of a Graduate Trainee the application will be granted, otherwise the application will be refused.

GTR 22.2. If the application is refused the person can apply for an Administrative Review under Appendix AR: Administrative Review.

metadata.section_title: Period and conditions of grant for a partner or child of a Graduate Trainee

chunks.text:
### Period and conditions of grant for a partner or child of a Graduate Trainee

GTR 23.1. A partner will be granted permission which ends on the same date as the person (P) who is their partner and has permission of a Graduate Trainee.

GTR 23.2. A child will be granted permission which ends on the same date as whichever of their parents’ permission ends first.

1.   GTR 23.3. The grant will be subject to all the following conditions: 
    1.   (a) no access to public funds; and
    2.   (b) work (including self-employment and voluntary work) permitted; except for employment as a professional sportsperson (including as a sports coach); and
    3.   (c) study is permitted, subject to the ATAS condition in Appendix ATAS.
    4.   (d) DELETED

The Global Business Mobility – UK Expansion Worker route is for overseas workers who are undertaking temporary work assignments in the UK, where the worker is a senior manager or specialist employee and is being assigned to the UK to undertake work related to a business’s expansion to the UK.

This route can only be used when the business has not yet begun trading in the UK. If the business is already trading in the UK, workers should apply under Appendix Global Business Mobility – Senior or Specialist Worker instead.

A dependent partner and dependent children can apply to come to the UK on this route.

The Global Business Mobility – UK Expansion Worker route is not a route to settlement.
chunks.summary: Partners and children of Graduate Trainees are granted permission for the same duration as the primary individual, with conditions including no public funds, permitted work (excluding professional sports), and study (subject to ATAS). Permissions end concurrently with the primary, and dependents' rights are limited to temporary residence without settlement prospects.

This route can only be used when the business has not yet begun trading in the UK. If the business is already trading in the UK, workers should apply under Appendix Global Business Mobility – Senior or Specialist Worker instead.

A dependent partner and dependent children can apply to come to the UK on this route.

The Global Business Mobility – UK Expansion Worker route is not a route to settlement.

metadata.section_title: Validity requirements for a Global Business Mobility - UK Expansion Worker (“UK Expansion Worker”)

chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for a Global Business Mobility - UK Expansion Worker (“UK Expansion Worker”)

1.   UKX 1.1. A person applying for entry clearance or permission to stay as a UK Expansion Worker must apply online on the gov.uk website on the specified form as follows: 
    1.   (a) for applicants outside the UK, form “Global Business Mobility visa”; or
    2.   (b) for applicants inside the UK, form “Global Business Mobility”.

2.   UKX 1.2. An application for entry clearance or permission to stay as a UK Expansion Worker must meet all the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) any fee and Immigration Health Charge must have been paid; and

3.   (b) the applicant must have provided biometrics when required; and 
    1.   (c) the applicant must have provided a passport or other travel document which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality; and
    2.   (d) the applicant must have a Certificate of Sponsorship that was issued to them by their sponsor no more than 3 months before the date of application.

UKX 1.3. The applicant must be aged 18 or over on the date of application.

UKX 1.4. An applicant applying for entry clearance or permission to stay as a UK Expansion Worker who has received an award from a Government or international scholarship agency in the 12 months before the date of application which covers both fees and living costs for study in the UK, must have provided written consent to the application from that Government or agency.

1.   UKX 1.5. If applying for permission to stay, the applicant must be in the UK on the date of application.
2.   UKX 1.5ZA. If applying for permission to stay, the applicant must not have, or have last been granted, permission: 
    1.   (a) as a Visitor; or
    2.   (b) as a Short-term Student; or
    3.   (c) as a Parent of a Child Student; or
    4.   (d) as a Seasonal Worker; or
    5.   (e) as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household; or
    6.   (f) outside the Immigration Rules.

1.   UKX 1.5A. An applicant who is applying for permission to stay and has, or last had, permission as a Student, must fulfil one of the Conditions A, B or C below on the date of application: 
    1.   (a) Condition A: the applicant must have completed the course of study for which the Confirmation of Acceptance for Studies was assigned (or a course to which ST 27.3 of Appendix Student applies); or
    2.   (b) Condition B: 
        1.   (i) the applicant must be studying a full-time course of study at degree level or above with a higher education provider which has a track record of compliance; and
        2.   (ii) the Certificate of Sponsorship in UKX 1.2(d) must have a start date no earlier than the course completion date; or

    3.   (c) Condition C: 
        1.   (i) the applicant must be studying a full-time course of study leading to the award of a PhD with a higher education provider which has a track record of compliance; and
        2.   (ii) the Certificate of Sponsorship in UKX 1.2(d) must have a start date no earlier than 24 months after the start date of that course.

UKX 1.6. An application which does not meet all the validity requirements for a UK Expansion Worker may be rejected as invalid and not considered.
chunks.summary: Applicants for UK Expansion Worker status must apply online, meet fee, biometric, and identification requirements, and hold a sponsor-issued Certificate of Sponsorship within three months. They must be at least 18 and, if recently scholarship-funded, provide written government consent.

metadata.section_title: Suitability requirements for a UK Expansion Worker

chunks.text:
### Suitability requirements for a UK Expansion Worker

UKX 2.1. The applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.

1.   UKX 2.2. If applying for permission to stay the applicant must not be: 
    1.   (a) in breach of immigration laws, except that where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, that period of overstaying will be disregarded; or
    2.   (b) on immigration bail.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to UK Expansion Workers seeking permission to stay. Applicants must not breach immigration laws (with certain exceptions) or be on immigration bail. Compliance with suitability and lawfulness is mandatory for approval.

metadata.section_title: Entry requirements for a UK Expansion Worker

chunks.text:
### Entry requirements for a UK Expansion Worker

UKX 3.1. A person seeking to come to the UK as a UK Expansion Worker must apply for and obtain entry clearance as a UK Expansion Worker before their arrival in the UK.

UKX 3.2. A person applying for entry clearance as a UK Expansion Worker must, if Appendix Tuberculosis applies, provide a valid medical certificate confirming that they have undergone screening for active pulmonary tuberculosis and that this tuberculosis is not present in them.
chunks.summary: Applicants seeking to enter the UK as a UK Expansion Worker must obtain prior entry clearance and, if applicable, provide a valid tuberculosis screening certificate. They must meet these requirements before arriving in the UK.

### Points requirement for a UK Expansion Worker

UKX 4.1. The applicant must be awarded all 60 points in the table below:

| Points requirements | Relevant rules | Points |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Sponsorship | UKX 5.1. to UKX 5.8. | 20 |
| Job at an appropriate skill level | UKX 6.1. to UKX 6.6. | 20 |
| Salary at required level | UKX 7.1. to UKX 9.3. | 20 |

1.   UKX 5.1. The applicant must have a valid certificate of sponsorship for the job they are planning to do, which to be valid must: 
    1.   (a) confirm the applicant’s name, that they are being sponsored as a UK Expansion Worker, details of the job, salary and any allowances the sponsor is offering them (if applicable) and PAYE details if HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) requires income tax and national insurance for the sponsored job to be paid via PAYE; and
    2.   (b) include a start date for the job, stated by the sponsor, which is no more than 3 months after the date of application; and
    3.   (c) not have been used in a previous application which was either granted or refused (but can have been used in a previous application which was rejected as invalid, made void or withdrawn); and
    4.   (d) not have been withdrawn by the sponsor or cancelled by the Home Office; and
    5.   (e) confirm that the applicant has worked for the sponsor group for the period required at UKX 5.6.(b); and
    6.   (f) confirm whether the Academic Technology Approval Scheme (ATAS) requirement in Appendix ATAS applies.

UKX 5.2. The sponsor must be authorised by the Home Office to sponsor a UK Expansion Worker.

1.   UKX 5.3. The sponsor must be listed as A-rated on the Home Office’s register of licensed sponsors, unless one of the following applies: 
    1.   (a) the applicant was last granted permission as a UK Expansion Worker and is applying to continue working for the same sponsor as in their last permission; or
    2.   (b) the applicant holds the role of authorising officer on the sponsor’s licence and the sponsor has a provisional rating on the Home Office’s register of licenced sponsors.

2.   UKX 5.4. The decision maker must not have reasonable grounds to believe the job the applicant is being sponsored to do: 
    1.   (a) does not exist; or
    2.   (b) is a sham; or
    3.   (c) has been created mainly so the applicant can apply for entry clearance or permission to stay.

3.   UKX 5.5. The sponsor must choose an appropriate SOC 2020 occupation code, and the decision maker must not have reasonable grounds to believe the job the applicant is being sponsored to do amounts to: 
    1.   (a) the hire of the applicant to a third party who is not the sponsor to fill a position with that party, whether temporary or permanent; or
    2.   (b) contract work to undertake an ongoing routine role or to provide an ongoing routine service for a third party who is not the sponsor, regardless of the nature or length of any arrangement between the sponsor and the third party.

4.   UKX 5.5A. The decision maker must not have reasonable grounds to believe the job the applicant is being sponsored to do does not comply with the National Minimum Wage Regulations or the Working Time Regulations.
5.   UKX 5.6. An applicant as a UK Expansion Worker must: 
    1.   (a) be currently working for the sponsor group; and
    2.   (b) have worked outside the UK for the sponsor group for a cumulative period of at least 12 months, unless the applicant is either: 
        1.   (i) applying as a high earner; or
        2.   (ii) a Japanese national seeking to establish a UK branch or subsidiary of the sponsor group under the UK-Japan Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement; or
        3.   (iii) a national or permanent resident of Australia seeking to establish a UK branch or subsidiary of the sponsor group under the Free Trade Agreement between the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and Australia (when the agreement comes into force or is provisionally applied).

6.   UKX 5.7. In UKX 5.6.(b) the 12 months’ work outside the UK can have been accumulated over any period provided that: 
    1.   (a) the applicant was continuously working for the business at UKX 5.6.(a), whether in or out of the UK, from the start of the 12 months to the date of application; and
    2.   (b) any breaks in the continuous work in UKX 5.7.(a) were only for the following reasons: 
        1.   (i) statutory maternity, paternity, parental, or shared parental leave; or
        2.   (ii) statutory adoption leave; or
        3.   (iii) sick leave; or
        4.   (iv) assisting with a national or international humanitarian or environmental crisis, with the agreement of the sponsor group; or
        5.   (v) taking part in legally organised industrial action; or
        6.   (vi) jury service; or
        7.   (vii) attending court as a witness.

UKX 5.8. If the requirements in UKX 5.1. to UKX 5.7. are met, the applicant will be awarded 20 points for sponsorship.

Critical conditions include that the sponsorship certificate has not been previously used or withdrawn, and compliance with relevant requirements like ATAS if applicable.

metadata.section_title: Points for job at appropriate skill level for a UK Expansion Worker

chunks.text:
### Points for job at appropriate skill level for a UK Expansion Worker

UKX 6.1. The applicant must be sponsored for a job in a SOC 2020 occupation code listed in Table 2 or Table 3 of Appendix Skilled Occupations.

UKX 6.1A. UKX 6.1A. If the date of application is before 4 April 2030, the applicant was granted permission as a UK Expansion Worker under the rules in place before 4 April 2024, and they have had continuous permission as a UK Expansion Worker since then (except that where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, that period of overstaying will be disregarded), they may be sponsored for a job in a SOC 2020 occupation code listed in Table 2b of Appendix Skilled Occupations.

1.   UKX 6.2. The decision maker must not have reasonable grounds to believe the sponsor has chosen a less appropriate SOC 2020 occupation code for any of the following reasons: 
    1.   (a) the most appropriate SOC 2020 occupation code is not eligible under the Global Business Mobility routes; or
    2.   (b) the most appropriate SOC 2020 occupation code has a higher going rate than the proposed salary.

2.   UKX 6.3. To support the assessment in UKX 6.2, the decision maker may, in particular, consider: 
    1.   (a) whether the sponsor has shown a genuine need for the job as described; and
    2.   (b) whether the applicant has the appropriate skills, qualifications and experience needed to do the job as described; and
    3.   (c) the sponsor’s history of compliance with the immigration system including, but not limited to, paying its sponsored workers appropriately; and
    4.   (d) any additional information from the sponsor.

UKX 6.4. If the ATAS requirement in Appendix ATAS applies, the applicant must provide a valid ATAS certificate.

UKX 6.5. If the requirements in UKX 6.1. to UKX 6.4. are met, the applicant will be awarded 20 points for a job at the appropriate skill level, subject to

UKX 6.6. UKX 6.6. No points will be awarded for a job at the appropriate skill level if the applicant is not also being awarded 20 points for sponsorship under UKX 5.8.
chunks.summary: Applicants must be sponsored for a job at an appropriate SOC 2020 skill level listed in the specified tables, with certain eligibility conditions for those with prior UK Expansion Worker permission before April 2024. Decision-makers assess the suitability of the SOC code, ensuring it's eligible under the routes and reflects appropriate salary levels, considering the sponsor's genuine need and the applicant’s skills. Exceptions apply for applicants with continuous permission before April 2024, subject to specific conditions.

metadata.section_title: Points for salary for a UK Expansion Worker

chunks.text:
### Points for salary for a UK Expansion Worker

1.   UKX 7.1. The salary for the job for which the applicant is being sponsored must equal or exceed both: 
    1.   (a) the general salary requirement in UKX 8.1 and UKX 8.2; and
    2.   (b) the going rate requirement in UKX 9.1. to UKX 9.3.

2.   UKX 7.2. Salary under these requirements includes only: 
    1.   (a) guaranteed basic gross pay (before income tax and including employee pension and national insurance contributions); and
    2.   (b) allowances which are guaranteed to be paid for the duration of the applicant’s employment in the UK (such as London weighting) or are paid as a mobility premium or to cover the additional cost of living in the UK.

UKX 7.3. Where allowances under UKX 7.2.(b) are solely for the purpose of accommodation they will only be taken into account up to a value of 30% of the total salary package.

1.   UKX 7.4. Salary does not include other pay and benefits, such as any of the following: 
    1.   (a) flexible working where the nature of the job means that hours fluctuate and pay cannot be guaranteed; or
    2.   (b) additional pay such as shift, overtime or bonus pay, whether or not it is guaranteed; or
    3.   (c) employer pension and national insurance contributions; or
    4.   (d) any allowances, other than those specified in UKX 7.2.(b); or
    5.   (e) in-kind benefits, such as equity shares, health insurance, school or university fees, company cars or food; or
    6.   (f) one-off payments, such as ‘golden hellos’; or
    7.   (g) any payments relating to immigration costs, such as the fee or Immigration Health Charge; or
    8.   (h) payments to cover business expenses, including (but not limited to) travel to and from the applicant’s country of residence, equipment, clothing, travel or subsistence.

UKX 7.5. If the requirements in UKX 7.1. to UKX 7.4. are met, the applicant will be awarded 20 points for salary at the required level, subject to UKX 7.6.

UKX 7.6. No points will be awarded for salary if the applicant is not also being awarded 20 points for sponsorship under UKX 5.8.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to UK Expansion Workers being sponsored under the Global Business Mobility route. Applicants' salary must meet or exceed both the general and going rate requirements, including guaranteed basic pay and certain allowances (e.g., London weighting), but excluding bonuses, benefits, and flexible pay. Allowances for accommodation count only up to 30% of the total salary.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Global Business Mobility routes
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Global Business Mobility routes
metadata.section_title: General salary requirement for a UK Expansion Worker

chunks.text:
### General salary requirement for a UK Expansion Worker

UKX 8.1. The general salary requirement is £52,500 per year.

UKX 8.2. If the applicant is being sponsored to work more than 48 hours a week, subject to UKX 8.3, only the salary for the first 48 hours a week will be considered towards the general salary requirement.

For example, an applicant who works 60 hours a week for £20 per hour will be considered to have a salary of £49,920 (£20 x 48 x 52) per year and not £62,400 (£20 x 60 x 52).

1.   UKX 8.3. If the applicant is being sponsored to work a pattern where the regular hours are not the same each week, resulting in uneven pay: 
    1.   (a) work in excess of 48 hours in some weeks can be considered towards the salary threshold of £52,500, providing the average over a regular cycle (which can be less than, but not more than, 17 weeks) is not more than 48 hours a week; and
    2.   (b) any unpaid rest weeks will count towards the average when considering whether the salary thresholds are met; and
    3.   (c) any unpaid rest weeks will not count as absences from employment for the purpose of paragraph SUI 36.1. in Part Suitability of these rules.

2.   For example, an applicant who works a pattern of 60 hours a week for £20 per hour for two weeks, followed by an unpaid rest week, will be considered to work 40 hours a week on average and have a salary of just £41,600 (£20 x 40 x 52) per year.
chunks.summary: The UKX 8.1 applies to UK Expansion Worker applicants, requiring a minimum salary of £52,500 annually. Salaries exceeding 48 hours work per week are only counted for the first 48 hours, with exceptions allowing average calculations over up to 17 weeks if hours vary. Unpaid rest weeks are included in averaging and do not count as absences.

metadata.section_title: Going rate requirement for a UK Expansion Worker

chunks.text:
### Going rate requirement for a UK Expansion Worker

UKX 9.1. If the applicant is being sponsored for a job in one of the SOC 2020 occupation codes listed in Table 2 or Table 2b of Appendix Skilled Occupations, the going rate requirement is 100% of the pro-rated going rate, which will be calculated as follows:

1 x (the going rate for the SOC 2020 occupation code stated in Table 2 or Table 2b of Appendix Skilled Occupations) x (the number of weekly working hours stated by the sponsor ÷ 37.5).

UKX 9.2. If the applicant is being sponsored for a job in one of the health or education SOC 2020 occupation codes listed in Table 3 of Appendix Skilled Occupations, the going rate requirement is 100% of the pro-rated going rate (and the going rate will be pro-rated according to the number of weekly working hours stated by the sponsor, and the pro-rating set out in Appendix Skilled Occupations).

UKX 9.3. The applicant’s full weekly hours will be included when checking their salary against the going rate, even if they work more than 48 hours a week.

For example, an applicant who works 60 hours a week in a SOC 2020 occupation code with a going rate of £75,000 must be paid £120,000 (1 x £75,000 x 60 ÷ 37.5) per year, not £96,000 (1 x £75,000 x 48 ÷ 37.5).
chunks.summary: This provision applies to UK Expansion Workers being sponsored in specific SOC 2020 occupation codes. It requires their salary to meet 100% of the pro-rated going rate based on weekly hours worked, including full-time hours over 48 per week; exceptions or thresholds are not specified.

metadata.section_title: Genuineness requirement for a UK Expansion Worker

chunks.text:
### Genuineness requirement for a UK Expansion Worker

1.   UKX 9A.1. The applicant must: 
    1.   (a) genuinely intend, and be able, to undertake the role for which they are being sponsored; and
    2.   (b) not intend to undertake employment other than in the role for which they are being sponsored, or as otherwise permitted by UKX 13.1.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to UK Expansion Workers. Applicants must genuinely intend and be able to perform their sponsored role and not seek employment outside permitted roles, ensuring the genuineness of their employment.

### Genuineness requirement for a UK Expansion Worker

1.   UKX 9A.1. The applicant must: 
    1.   (a) genuinely intend, and be able, to undertake the role for which they are being sponsored; and
    2.   (b) not intend to undertake employment other than in the role for which they are being sponsored, or as otherwise permitted by UKX 13.1.

metadata.section_title: Financial requirement for a UK Expansion Worker

chunks.text:
### Financial requirement for a UK Expansion Worker

UKX 10.1. If the applicant is applying for permission to stay and has been living in the UK with permission for 12 months or longer on the date of application, they will meet the financial requirement and do not need to show funds.

UKX 10.2. If the applicant is applying for entry clearance or has been living in the UK for less than 12 months, the applicant must have funds of at least £1,270.

UKX 10.3. The applicant must show that they have held the level of funds required by UKX 10.2. for a 28-day period and as set out in Appendix Finance.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to UK Expansion Workers seeking permission to stay or entry clearance. Applicants residing in the UK for 12 months or more meet the financial requirement automatically; those with less than 12 months must have at least £1,270 held for 28 days. No funds are needed if the applicant has been in the UK with permission for a year or longer.
chunks.augmented_text:
Document: Immigration Rules Appendix Global Business Mobility routes

Section ID: UKX 10.1
Section: Financial requirement for a UK Expansion Worker
Topic: financial

Summary: This provision applies to UK Expansion Workers seeking permission to stay or entry clearance. Applicants residing in the UK for 12 months or more meet the financial requirement automatically; those with less than 12 months must have at least £1,270 held for 28 days. No funds are needed if the applicant has been in the UK with permission for a year or longer.

### Financial requirement for a UK Expansion Worker

UKX 10.1. If the applicant is applying for permission to stay and has been living in the UK with permission for 12 months or longer on the date of application, they will meet the financial requirement and do not need to show funds.

UKX 10.2. If the applicant is applying for entry clearance or has been living in the UK for less than 12 months, the applicant must have funds of at least £1,270.

UKX 10.3. The applicant must show that they have held the level of funds required by UKX 10.2. for a 28-day period and as set out in Appendix Finance.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Global Business Mobility routes
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Global Business Mobility routes
metadata.section_title: Maximum length of assignments requirement for a UK Expansion Worker

chunks.text:
### Maximum length of assignments requirement for a UK Expansion Worker

UKX 11.1. The grant of permission must not lead to the applicant being granted cumulative periods of permission in the Global Business Mobility routes and Intra-Company routes totalling more than 5 years in any 6-year period.

1.   UKX 11.2. When calculating the cumulative periods of permission referred to in UKX 11.1. and UKX 13.2.(d), the decision maker will include the following: 
    1.   (a) all previous periods of permission on the Global Business Mobility routes; and
    2.   (b) all previous periods of permission on the Intra-Company routes; and
    3.   (c) if the applicant does not currently hold permission on a Global Business Mobility route, any permission they could be granted under this application, beginning on the start date of the job stated on the Certificate of Sponsorship; and
    4.   (d) if the applicant is applying for permission to stay and has or last had permission on the Global Business Mobility routes, any permission they could be granted under this application, beginning on the date of decision; and
    5.   (e) any period of permission on the Global Business Mobility routes and the Intra-Company routes extended under section 3C of the Immigration Act 1971.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to UK Expansion Workers under the Global Business Mobility routes, limiting their total permission to 5 years within any 6-year period. It requires that cumulative periods, including previous permissions and extensions, do not exceed this threshold, with specific rules for calculating ongoing and potential permissions. Exceeding this limit restricts further permission grants under these routes.

metadata.section_title: Decision on an application as a UK Expansion Worker

chunks.text:
### Decision on an application as a UK Expansion Worker

UKX 12.1. If the decision maker is satisfied that all the suitability and eligibility requirements for a UK Expansion Worker are met the application will be granted, otherwise the application will be refused.

UKX 12.2. If the application is refused the person can apply for an Administrative Review under Appendix AR: Administrative Review.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to UK Expansion Worker applicants, requiring that all suitability and eligibility criteria are met for their application to be granted. If refused, applicants have the right to an Administrative Review, with no specific thresholds or exceptions mentioned.

metadata.section_title: Period and conditions of grant as a UK Expansion Worker

chunks.text:
### Period and conditions of grant as a UK Expansion Worker

1.   UKX 13.1. The grant will be subject to all the following conditions: 
    1.   (a) no access to public funds; and
    2.   (b) the only work permitted is: 
        1.   (i) the job for which the applicant is being sponsored; and
        2.   (ii) voluntary work; and
        3.   (iii) working out a contractual notice period, where the applicant was lawfully working in that job in the UK on the date of application; and

    3.   (c) study is permitted, subject to the ATAS condition in Appendix ATAS.
    4.   (d) DELETED

2.   UKX 13.2. Permission will be granted for a period which is the shortest of the following: 
    1.   (a) 1 year after the start date of the job detailed in the Certificate of Sponsorship; or
    2.   (b) 14 days after the end date of the job detailed in the Certificate of Sponsorship; or
    3.   (c) the date at which the applicant will have had continuous permission as a UK Expansion Worker totalling 2 years; or
    4.   (d) the date at which the applicant will have had cumulative permission in the Global Business Mobility routes totalling 5 years in any 6-year period.

UKX 13.3. If the applicant does not currently hold permission on the Global Business Mobility routes, any permission granted for the period between the date of decision and the start date of the job detailed in the Certificate of Sponsorship will be excluded from the cumulative permission for the purpose of determining the period of grant of permission under UKX 13.2. (but not from the cumulative period in UKX 11.2.).
chunks.summary: This provision applies to UK Expansion Workers, outlining the conditions for their permission. It specifies the permissible work, study, and restrictions (no public funds), with permission duration limited to the shortest of specified timeframes up to 2 years of continuous or 5 years cumulative within six years. Exceptions include voluntary work and contractual notice periods.

metadata.section_title: Validity requirements for a partner or child of a UK Expansion Worker

chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for a partner or child of a UK Expansion Worker

UKX 14.1. A person applying for entry clearance or permission to stay as a partner or child of a UK Expansion Worker must apply online on the gov.uk website on the specified form as follows:

| Applicant | Specified form |
| --- | --- |
| Applicants outside the UK | Dependant partner visa Dependant child visa |
| Applicants inside the UK | Dependant partner Dependant child |

1.   UKX 14.2. An application for entry clearance or permission to stay as a partner or child of a UK Expansion Worker must meet all the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) any fee and Immigration Health Charge must have been paid; and
    2.   (b) the applicant must have provided biometrics when required; and
    3.   (c) the applicant must have provided either a passport or other travel document which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality; and
    4.   (d) the applicant must be applying as partner or child of a person who: 
        1.   (i) has made a valid application for entry clearance or permission to stay on the Global Business Mobility – UK Expansion Worker route that has not been decided; or
        2.   (ii) has entry clearance or permission to stay on the Global Business Mobility – UK Expansion Worker route.

UKX 14.3. A person applying as a partner must be aged 18 or over on the date of application.

1.   UKX 14.4. If applying for permission to stay, the applicant must be in the UK on the date of application.
2.   UKX 14.4ZA. If applying for permission to stay, the applicant must not have, or have last been granted, permission: 
    1.   (a) as a Visitor; or
    2.   (b) as a Short-term Student; or
    3.   (c) as a Parent of a Child Student; or
    4.   (d) as a Seasonal Worker; or
    5.   (e) as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household; or
    6.   (f) outside the Immigration Rules.

1.   UKX 14.4A. An applicant who is applying for permission to stay and has, or last had, permission as a Student, must fulfil one of the Conditions A or B below on the date of application: 
    1.   (a) Condition A: the applicant must have completed the course of study for which the Confirmation of Acceptance for Studies was assigned (or a course to which ST 27.3 of Appendix Student applies); or
    2.   (b) Condition B: the applicant must: 
        1.   (i) be studying a full-time course of study leading to the award of a PhD with a higher education provider which has a track record of compliance; and
        2.   (ii) have completed at least 24 months of study on that course.

UKX 14.5. An application which does not meet all the validity requirements for a partner or child of a UK Expansion Worker may be rejected as invalid and not considered.
chunks.summary: Eligible partners or children of UK Expansion Workers must apply online using specific forms, pay required fees and health charges, provide biometrics and travel documents, and be related to an individual already with valid UK immigration status on the route. Applicants for partners must be at least 18 years old, and applications are only valid if the main worker’s application is pending or approved.

metadata.section_title: Suitability requirements for a partner or child of a UK Expansion Worker

chunks.text:
### Suitability requirements for a partner or child of a UK Expansion Worker

UKX 15.1. The applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.

1.   UKX 15.2. If applying for permission to stay the applicant must not be: 
    1.   (a) in breach of immigration laws, except that where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, that period of overstaying will be disregarded; or
    2.   (b) on immigration bail.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to partners or children of UK Expansion Workers applying for permission to stay. They must not breach immigration laws (with some exceptions) or be on immigration bail. These suitability requirements aim to ensure lawful conduct prior to approval.

metadata.section_title: Entry requirement for a partner or child of a UK Expansion Worker

chunks.text:
### Entry requirement for a partner or child of a UK Expansion Worker

UKX 16.1. A person seeking to come to the UK as a partner or child must apply for and obtain entry clearance as a partner or child of a UK Expansion Worker before they arrive in the UK.

UKX 16.2. A person applying for entry clearance as the partner or child of a UK Expansion Worker must, if Appendix Tuberculosis applies, provide a valid medical certificate confirming that they have undergone screening for active pulmonary tuberculosis and that this tuberculosis is not present in them.
chunks.summary: Partners and children of UK Expansion Workers must obtain entry clearance before arriving in the UK. Applicants must, where applicable, provide a tuberculosis test certificate confirming they are free of active pulmonary TB.

### Relationship requirement for a partner of a UK Expansion Worker

1.   UKX 17.1. The applicant must be the partner of a person (P) where one of the following applies: 
    1.   (a) P has permission on the Global Business Mobility – UK Expansion Worker route; or
    2.   (b) P is, at the same time, applying for (and is granted) entry clearance or permission on the Global Business Mobility – UK Expansion Worker route.

UKX 17.2. The requirements of Appendix Relationship with Partner must be met.

UKX 17.3. DELETED

UKX 17.4. DELETED

### Financial requirement for a partner or child of a UK Expansion Worker

UKX 21.1. If the applicant is applying for permission to stay and has been living in the UK with permission for 12 months or longer on the date of application, they will meet the financial requirement and do not need to show funds.

1.   UKX 21.2. If the applicant is applying for entry clearance, or is applying for permission to stay and has not been in the UK for 12 months on the date of application, funds of at least the amount required in UKX 21.3. must be held collectively by one or more of the following: 
    1.   (a) the applicant; and
    2.   (b) the UK Expansion Worker (P); and
    3.   (c) if the applicant is applying as a child, their parent who is lawfully present in the UK or being granted entry clearance, or permission to stay, at the same time.

2.   UKX 21.3. The required funds are: 
    1.   (a) £285 for a partner in the UK or applying for entry clearance; and
    2.   (b) £315 for the first child in the UK or applying for entry clearance; and
    3.   (c) £200 for any other child in the UK or applying for entry clearance.

UKX 21.4. If UKX 23.2.(a) applies, the funds held must be held in addition to any funds required for the UK Expansion Worker to meet the financial requirement and the funds required for any dependants in the UK or applying at the same time.

UKX 21.5. If UKX 23.2.(a) applies, the funds must have been held for a 28-day period and as specified in Appendix Finance.

They must demonstrate holding specified funds (£285 for a partner, £315 for the first child, and £200 for additional children) unless residing in the UK for 12+ months, in which case the financial requirement is waived. Additional funds may be required if certain conditions apply, and funds must be held for 28 days if specified.

metadata.section_title: Decision on an application as a partner or child of a UK Expansion Worker

chunks.text:
### Decision on an application as a partner or child of a UK Expansion Worker

UKX 22.1. If the decision maker is satisfied that all the suitability and eligibility requirements are met for a partner or child of a UK Expansion Worker the application will be granted, otherwise the application will be refused.

UKX 22.2. If the application is refused the person can apply for an Administrative Review under Appendix AR: Administrative Review.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to partners or children of UK Expansion Workers. It requires the decision-maker to verify all suitability and eligibility criteria before granting the application; failure results in refusal, but an Administrative Review can be requested.

metadata.section_title: Period and conditions of grant for a partner or child of a UK Expansion Worker

chunks.text:
### Period and conditions of grant for a partner or child of a UK Expansion Worker

UKX 23.1. A partner will be granted permission which ends on the same date as the person (P) who is their partner and has permission as a UK Expansion Worker.

UKX 23.2. A child will be granted permission which ends on the same date as whichever of their parents’ permission ends first.

1.   UKX 23.3. The grant will be subject to all the following conditions: 
    1.   (a) no access to public funds; and
    2.   (b) work (including self-employment and voluntary work) permitted; except for employment as a professional sportsperson (including as a sports coach); and
    3.   (c) study is permitted, subject to the ATAS condition in Appendix ATAS.
    4.   (d) DELETED

The Global Business Mobility – Service Supplier route is for overseas workers who are undertaking temporary work assignments in the UK, where the worker is either a contractual service supplier employed by an overseas service provider or a self-employed independent professional based overseas, and they need to undertake an assignment in the UK to provide services covered by one of the UK’s international trade agreements.

A dependent partner and dependent children can apply to come to the UK on this route.

The Global Business Mobility – Service Supplier route is not a route to settlement.
chunks.summary: Partners' and children's permissions align with the UK Expansion Worker's validity, limited by restrictions on public funds, work (excluding professional sports), and study with ATAS. Dependent permissions end concurrently with the primary permit and do not lead to settlement.

metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Global Business Mobility routes
metadata.section_title: Validity requirements for a Global Business Mobility - Service Supplier (“Service Supplier”)

chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for a Global Business Mobility - Service Supplier (“Service Supplier”)

1.   SSU 1.1. A person applying for entry clearance or permission to stay as a Service Supplier must apply online on the gov.uk website on the specified form as follows: 
    1.   (a) for applicants outside the UK, form “Global Business Mobility visa”; or
    2.   (b) for applicants inside the UK, form “Global Business Mobility”.

2.   SSU 1.2. An application for entry clearance or permission to stay as a Service Supplier must meet all the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) any fee and Immigration Health Charge must have been paid; and
    2.   (b) the applicant must have provided biometrics when required; and
    3.   (c) the applicant must have provided a passport or other travel document which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality; and
    4.   (d) the applicant must have a Certificate of Sponsorship that was issued to them by their sponsor no more than 3 months before the date of application.

SSU 1.3. The applicant must be aged 18 or over on the date of application.

SSU 1.4. An applicant applying for entry clearance or permission to stay as a Service Supplier who has received an award from a Government or international scholarship agency in the 12 months before the date of application which covers both fees and living costs for study in the UK, must have provided written consent to the application from that Government or agency.

1.   SSU 1.5. If applying for permission to stay, the applicant must be in the UK on the date of application.
2.   SSU 1.5ZA. If applying for permission to stay, the applicant must not have, or have last been granted, permission: 
    1.   (a) as a Visitor; or
    2.   (b) as a Short-term Student; or
    3.   (c) as a Parent of a Child Student; or
    4.   (d) as a Seasonal Worker; or
    5.   (e) as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household; or
    6.   (f) outside the Immigration Rules.

1.   SSU 1.5A. An applicant who is applying for permission to stay and has, or last had, permission as a Student, must fulfil one of the Conditions A, B or C below on the date of application: 
    1.   (a) Condition A: the applicant must have completed the course of study for which the Confirmation of Acceptance for Studies was assigned (or a course to which ST 27.3 of Appendix Student applies); or
    2.   (b) Condition B: 
        1.   (i) the applicant must be studying a full-time course of study at degree level or above with a higher education provider which has a track record of compliance; and
        2.   (ii) the Certificate of Sponsorship in SSU 1.2(d) must have a start date no earlier than the course completion date; or

    3.   (c) Condition C: 
        1.   (i) the applicant must be studying a full-time course of study leading to the award of a PhD with a higher education provider which has a track record of compliance; and
        2.   (ii) the Certificate of Sponsorship in SSU 1.2(d) must have a start date no earlier than 24 months after the start date of that course.

SSU 1.6. An application which does not meet all the validity requirements for a Service Supplier may be rejected as invalid and not considered.
chunks.summary: Service Suppliers applying for UK entry or stay must submit online applications, pay fees and health charges, provide biometrics, identity documents, and a valid sponsor certificate issued within 3 months. Applicants must be at least 18 and, if sponsored by a government scholarship covering costs in the past 12 months, must obtain written consent from the agency.

metadata.section_title: Suitability requirements for a Service Supplier

chunks.text:
### Suitability requirements for a Service Supplier

SSU 2.1. The applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.

1.   SSU 2.2. If applying for permission to stay the applicant must not be: 
    1.   (a) in breach of immigration laws, except that where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, that period of overstaying will be disregarded; or
    2.   (b) on immigration bail.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to Service Suppliers applying for permission to stay under the Global Business Mobility route. Applicants must not breach immigration laws or be on immigration bail, with certain overstaying exceptions.

metadata.section_title: Entry requirements for a Service Supplier

chunks.text:
### Entry requirements for a Service Supplier

SSU 3.1. A person seeking to come to the UK as a Service Supplier must apply for and obtain entry clearance as a Service Supplier before their arrival in the UK.

SSU 3.2. A person applying for entry clearance as a Service Supplier must, if Appendix Tuberculosis applies, provide a valid medical certificate confirming that they have undergone screening for active pulmonary tuberculosis and that this tuberculosis is not present in them.
chunks.summary: Service Suppliers seeking entry to the UK must obtain prior entry clearance, including medical screening for tuberculosis if applicable, before arrival.
chunks.augmented_text:

Section ID: SSU 3.1
Section: Entry requirements for a Service Supplier
Topic: leave-to-enter

Summary: Service Suppliers seeking entry to the UK must obtain prior entry clearance, including medical screening for tuberculosis if applicable, before arrival.

### Entry requirements for a Service Supplier

SSU 3.1. A person seeking to come to the UK as a Service Supplier must apply for and obtain entry clearance as a Service Supplier before their arrival in the UK.

SSU 3.2. A person applying for entry clearance as a Service Supplier must, if Appendix Tuberculosis applies, provide a valid medical certificate confirming that they have undergone screening for active pulmonary tuberculosis and that this tuberculosis is not present in them.

metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Global Business Mobility routes
metadata.section_title: Points requirement for a Service Supplier

chunks.text:
### Points requirement for a Service Supplier

SSU 4.1. The applicant must be awarded all 40 points in the table below:

| Points requirements | Relevant rules | Points |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Sponsorship | SSU 5.1. to SSU 5.7. | 20 |
| Job at an appropriate skill level (option A) or Job at an appropriate skill level (option B) | SSU 6.1. to SSU 6.6. SSU 7.1. to SSU 7.5. | 20 |

SSU 4.2. An applicant as a Service Supplier can be awarded 20 points by meeting the requirements of either SSU 6.1. to SSU 6.6. or SSU 7.1. to SSU 7.5.

1.   SSU 5.1. The applicant must have a valid certificate of sponsorship for the job they are planning to do, which must: 
    1.   (a) confirm the applicant’s name, that they are being sponsored as a Service Supplier, and details of the job the sponsor is offering them; and
    2.   (b) include a start date for the job, stated by the sponsor, which is no more than 3 months after the date of application; and
    3.   (c) not have been used in a previous application which was either granted or refused (but can have been used in a previous application which was rejected as invalid, made void or withdrawn); and
    4.   (d) not have been withdrawn by the sponsor or cancelled by the Home Office; and
    5.   (e) DELETED
    6.   (f) confirm whether the Academic Technology Approval Scheme (ATAS) requirement in Appendix ATAS applies; and
    7.   (g) confirm which of the sponsor’s contracts registered with the Home Office the applicant will work on.

SSU 5.2. The sponsor must be authorised by the Home Office to sponsor a Service Supplier.

SSU 5.3. The sponsor must be listed as A-rated on the Home Office’s register of licensed sponsors, unless the applicant was last granted permission as a Service Supplier and is applying to continue working for the same sponsor as in their last permission.

1.   SSU 5.4. The sponsor must have a contract with an overseas service provider, where that contract: 
    1.   (a) has been registered with the Home Office; and
    2.   (b) is for a service covered by: 
        1.   (i) one of the UK’s international trade agreements (other than the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP)) where that agreement is currently in force or provisionally applied; or;
        2.   (ii) the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), where the Protocol on the Accession of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland to that agreement has entered into force for the UK, and both the country where the overseas service provider is located, and the country of which the service supplier is a national, have ratified the UK’s accession to the agreement.

    3.   (c) is the contract on which the applicant will work as a Service Supplier.

2.   SSU 5.5. The decision maker must not have reasonable grounds to believe the job the applicant is being sponsored to do: 
    1.   (a) does not exist; or
    2.   (b) is a sham; or
    3.   (c) has been created mainly so the applicant can apply for entry clearance or permission to stay.

3.   SSU 5.6. The decision maker must not have reasonable grounds to believe the job the applicant is being sponsored to do amounts to: 
    1.   (a) the hire of the applicant to a third party who is not the sponsor to fill a position with that party, whether temporary or permanent; or
    2.   (b) contract work to undertake an ongoing routine role or to provide an ongoing routine service for a third party who is not the sponsor, regardless of the nature or length of any arrangement between the sponsor and the third party.

4.   SSU 5.6A. The decision maker must not have reasonable grounds to believe the job the applicant is being sponsored to do does not comply with the National Minimum Wage Regulations or the Working Time Regulations.

SSU 5.7. If the requirements in SSU 5.1. to SSU 5.6. are met, the applicant will be awarded 20 points for sponsorship.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to Service Suppliers under the UK Global Business Mobility routes. They must score all 40 points by meeting sponsorship requirements (20 points) and either skill level or job duration criteria (20 points). Critical conditions include holding a valid sponsorship certificate with specific details and ensuring it hasn't been previously used or withdrawn.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Global Business Mobility routes
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Global Business Mobility routes
metadata.section_title: Points for job at appropriate skill level for a Service Supplier – Option A

chunks.text:
### Points for job at appropriate skill level for a Service Supplier – Option A

SSU 6.1. The applicant must be sponsored for a job in an SOC 2020 occupation code listed in Table 2 or Table 3 of Appendix Skilled Occupations.

SSU 6.1A. If the date of application is before 4 April 2030, the applicant was granted permission as a Service Supplier under the rules in place before 4 April 2024, and they have had continuous permission as a Service Supplier since then (except that where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, that period of overstaying will be disregarded), they may be sponsored for a job in a SOC 2020 occupation code listed in Table 2b of Appendix Skilled Occupations.

SSU 6.2. The sponsor must choose an appropriate SOC 2020 occupation code, and the decision maker must not have reasonable grounds to believe the sponsor has chosen a less appropriate SOC 2020 occupation code due to the most appropriate SOC 2020 occupation code not being eligible under the Global Business Mobility routes.

1.   SSU 6.3. To support the assessment in SSU 6.2., the decision maker may, in particular, consider: 
    1.   (a) whether the sponsor has shown a genuine need for the job as described; and
    2.   (b) whether the applicant has the appropriate skills, qualifications and experience needed to do the job as described; and
    3.   (c) the sponsor’s history of compliance with the immigration system including, but not limited to, paying its sponsored workers appropriately; and
    4.   (d) any additional information from the sponsor.

SSU 6.4. If the ATAS requirement in Appendix ATAS applies, the applicant must provide a valid ATAS certificate.

SSU 6.5. If the requirements in SSU 6.1. to SSU 6.4. are met, the applicant will be awarded 20 points for a job at the appropriate skill level, subject to SSU 6.6.

SSU 6.6. No points will be awarded for a job at the appropriate skill level if the applicant is not also being awarded 20 points for sponsorship under SSU 5.7.
chunks.summary: Applicants must be sponsored for a job in an appropriate SOC 2020 occupation code under the Global Business Mobility routes, with specific provisions for those with prior continuous service supplier permissions before 4 April 2024. Sponsors must select an appropriate SOC code, justified by genuine need, applicant’s skills, and sponsor’s compliance, with limited exceptions for certain pre-2024 permissions.
chunks.augmented_text:
Document: Immigration Rules Appendix Global Business Mobility routes
Part: Immigration Rules Appendix Global Business Mobility routes
Section ID: SSU 6.1
Section: Points for job at appropriate skill level for a Service Supplier – Option A
Topic: points

Summary: Applicants must be sponsored for a job in an appropriate SOC 2020 occupation code under the Global Business Mobility routes, with specific provisions for those with prior continuous service supplier permissions before 4 April 2024. Sponsors must select an appropriate SOC code, justified by genuine need, applicant’s skills, and sponsor’s compliance, with limited exceptions for certain pre-2024 permissions.

### Points for job at appropriate skill level for a Service Supplier – Option A

SSU 6.1. The applicant must be sponsored for a job in an SOC 2020 occupation code listed in Table 2 or Table 3 of Appendix Skilled Occupations.

SSU 6.1A. If the date of application is before 4 April 2030, the applicant was granted permission as a Service Supplier under the rules in place before 4 April 2024, and they have had continuous permission as a Service Supplier since then (except that where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, that period of overstaying will be disregarded), they may be sponsored for a job in a SOC 2020 occupation code listed in Table 2b of Appendix Skilled Occupations.

SSU 6.2. The sponsor must choose an appropriate SOC 2020 occupation code, and the decision maker must not have reasonable grounds to believe the sponsor has chosen a less appropriate SOC 2020 occupation code due to the most appropriate SOC 2020 occupation code not being eligible under the Global Business Mobility routes.

1.   SSU 6.3. To support the assessment in SSU 6.2., the decision maker may, in particular, consider: 
    1.   (a) whether the sponsor has shown a genuine need for the job as described; and
    2.   (b) whether the applicant has the appropriate skills, qualifications and experience needed to do the job as described; and
    3.   (c) the sponsor’s history of compliance with the immigration system including, but not limited to, paying its sponsored workers appropriately; and
    4.   (d) any additional information from the sponsor.

SSU 6.4. If the ATAS requirement in Appendix ATAS applies, the applicant must provide a valid ATAS certificate.

SSU 6.5. If the requirements in SSU 6.1. to SSU 6.4. are met, the applicant will be awarded 20 points for a job at the appropriate skill level, subject to SSU 6.6.

SSU 6.6. No points will be awarded for a job at the appropriate skill level if the applicant is not also being awarded 20 points for sponsorship under SSU 5.7.

metadata.section_title: Points for job at appropriate skill level for a Service Supplier – Option B

chunks.text:
### Points for job at appropriate skill level for a Service Supplier – Option B

SSU 7.1. The applicant must have a university degree or equivalent level technical qualification unless they are employed by an overseas service provider supplying one of the following services, in which case the qualification requirements in the following table apply:

| Services | Qualification |
| --- | --- |
| Fashion and modelling | None required |
| Chef de cuisine | An advanced technical qualification |
| Entertainment services (excluding audio-visual services under the CARIFORUM-UK Economic Partnership Agreement) | None required |
| Management consulting services and services related to management consulting (managers and senior consultants) | University degree (equivalent level technical qualification not permitted) |
| Advertising or translation | Relevant qualifications |
| Technical testing and analysis | University degree or a relevant technical qualification |

SSU 7.2. The applicant must hold any professional qualifications or registrations required to provide the services under UK law or sectoral requirements.

1.   SSU 7.3. The applicant must have professional experience in the sector in which they will supply services as follows: 
    1.   (a) 3 years’ experience; or
    2.   (b) if they are supplying chef de cuisine services under the CARIFORUM-UK Economic Partnership Agreement, 6 years’ experience; or
    3.   (c) if they are a self-employed overseas service provider, 6 years’ experience.

SSU 7.4. If the requirements in SSU 7.1. to SSU 7.3. are met, the applicant will be awarded 20 points for a job at the appropriate skill level, subject to SSU 7.5.

SSU 7.5. No points will be awarded for a job at the appropriate skill level if the applicant is not also being awarded 20 points for sponsorship under SSU 5.7.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to Service Suppliers seeking entry under the UK Global Business Mobility routes. Applicants must possess relevant qualifications or professional experience—typically a university degree or sector-specific credentials and 3-6 years’ experience—unless supplying certain services (e.g., fashion, entertainment) with no qualification required. Conditions include compliance with UK legal and sectoral registration requirements.

metadata.section_title: Nationality requirement for a Service Supplier

chunks.text:
### Nationality requirement for a Service Supplier

1.   SSU 8.1. The applicant must be: 
    1.   (a) a national of the country or territory in which the overseas service provider is based; or
    2.   (b) where the service that the applicant will provide is covered by a commitment in the General Agreement on Trade in Services and the applicant’s employer is established in a country or territory that has made a notification under Article XXVIII(k)(ii)(2) of that agreement, a permanent resident of that country or territory; or
    3.   (c) where the service that the applicant will provide is covered by a commitment in the Temporary Agreement between the Swiss Confederation and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland on Services Mobility, a permanent resident of Switzerland; or
    4.   (d) where the service that the applicant will provide is covered by a commitment in the United Kingdom-European Union Trade and Cooperation Agreement, a national of any Member State of the European Union or any other person included in the definition of “natural person of a Party” for the European Union in Article 512(k) of that agreement; or
    5.   (e) where the service that the applicant will provide is covered by a contractual service supplier commitment in the CARIFORUM-United Kingdom Economic Partnership Agreement, a national of any CARIFORUM State that has provisionally applied or brought into force that agreement; or
    6.   (f) where the service that the applicant will provide is covered by a commitment in the Free Trade Agreement between the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and Australia, a permanent resident of Australia; or
    7.   (g) where the service that the applicant will provide is covered by a commitment in the Free Trade Agreement between the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and New Zealand, a permanent resident of New Zealand; or
    8.   (h) where the service that the applicant will provide is covered by a commitment in the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), a national of a party to that agreement or a permanent resident of Australia, Canada or New Zealand, subject to the provisions of paragraph (i);
    9.   (i) Where the commitment in the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) falls into a category in the first column of the table, the applicant must be a national of a country in the second column of the table below (or to the extent that Australia, Canada or New Zealand is listed in that column, a permanent resident of that country):

| Category | CPTPP Parties with access |
| --- | --- |
| **Contractual Service Suppliers** | Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, Peru, Vietnam |
| **Independent Professionals** | Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, Peru, New Zealand |
chunks.summary: This provision applies to Service Suppliers applying under the Global Business Mobility route. Applicants must be nationals or permanent residents of specified countries or territories, depending on the trade agreement covering their services. Critical conditions include compliance with relevant international agreements, with certain thresholds based on the applicant’s nationality or residence.

metadata.section_title: Overseas work requirement for a Service Supplier

chunks.text:
### Overseas work requirement for a Service Supplier

1.   SSU 9.1. The applicant must: 
    1.   (a) be currently working as or for an overseas service provider that will provide services to the sponsor; and
    2.   (b) have worked as or for the overseas service provider outside the UK for a cumulative period of 12 months.

1.   SSU 9.2. In SSU 9.1. the 12 months’ work outside the UK can have been accumulated over any period provided that: 
    1.   (a) the applicant was either: 
        1.   (i) continuously working for the overseas service provider at SSU 9.1., whether in or out of the UK, from the start of the 12 months to the date of application; or
        2.   (ii) if the applicant is a self-employed overseas service provider, continuously working in the same sector as the service they will provide to the sponsor, whether in or out of the UK, from the start of the 12 months to the date of application; and

    2.   (b) any breaks in the continuous work in SSU 9.2.(a) were only for the following reasons: 
        1.   (i) statutory maternity, paternity, parental, or shared parental leave; or
        2.   (ii) statutory adoption leave; or
        3.   (iii) sick leave; or
        4.   (iv) assisting with a national or international humanitarian or environmental crisis, with the agreement of the overseas service provider; or
        5.   (v) taking part in legally organised industrial action; or
        6.   (vi) jury service; or
        7.   (vii) attending court as a witness.
chunks.summary: The provision applies to overseas service providers seeking to supply services to a UK sponsor. The applicant must have worked for the overseas provider outside the UK for at least 12 months, with continuous employment or sector work, allowing for certain approved breaks. These conditions ensure relevant experience is demonstrated for eligibility.

metadata.section_title: Genuineness requirement for a Service Supplier

chunks.text:
### Genuineness requirement for a Service Supplier

1.   SSU 9A.1. The applicant must: 
    1.   (a) genuinely intend, and be able, to undertake the role for which they are being sponsored; and
    2.   (b) not intend to undertake employment other than in the role for which they are being sponsored, or as otherwise permitted by SSU 13.1.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to Service Suppliers seeking sponsorship under the Global Business Mobility route. Applicants must genuinely intend and be able to undertake their sponsored role and not engage in unrelated employment unless permitted. The rule emphasizes the authenticity of the role and limits employment to the sponsored position.

metadata.section_title: Financial requirement for a Service Supplier

chunks.text:
### Financial requirement for a Service Supplier

SSU 10.1. If the applicant is applying for permission to stay and has been living in the UK with permission for 12 months or longer on the date of application, they will meet the financial requirement and do not need to show funds.

1.   SSU 10.2. If the applicant is applying for entry clearance or has been living in the UK for less than 12 months on the date of application either: 
    1.   (a) the applicant must have funds of at least £1,270; or
    2.   (b) the applicant’s A-rated sponsor must confirm on the Certificate of Sponsorship that they will, if it is necessary, maintain and accommodate the applicant up to the end of the first month of their employment to an amount of at least £1,270.

SSU 10.3. If SSU 10.2.(a) applies, the applicant must show that they have held the required level of funds for a 28-day period and as set out in Appendix Finance.
chunks.summary: Service Suppliers applying for UK permission must either have been living in the UK for 12+ months (automatically meeting the financial requirement) or demonstrate funds of at least £1,270 (if under 12 months), with funds held for 28 days or be supported by an A-rated sponsor to cover accommodations and maintenance.

metadata.section_title: Maximum length of assignments requirement for a Service Supplier

chunks.text:
### Maximum length of assignments requirement for a Service Supplier

SSU 11.1. The grant of permission must not lead to the applicant being granted cumulative periods of permission on the Global Business Mobility routes and Intra-Company routes totalling more than 5 years in any 6-year period.

1.   SSU 11.2. When calculating the cumulative periods of permission referred to in SSU 11.1., the decision maker will include the following: 
    1.   (a) all previous periods of permission on the Global Business Mobility routes; and
    2.   (b) all previous periods of permission on the Intra-Company routes; and
    3.   (c) if the applicant does not currently hold permission in the Global Business Mobility routes, any permission they could be granted under this application, beginning on the start date of the job stated on the Certificate of Sponsorship; and
    4.   (d) if the applicant is applying for permission to stay and has or last had permission on the Global Business Mobility routes, any permission they could be granted under this application, beginning on the date of decision; and
    5.   (e) any period of permission on the Global Business Mobility routes and the Intra-Company routes extended under section 3C of the Immigration Act 1971.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to Service Suppliers under UK Global Business Mobility routes. It requires that their total permission periods on these routes and Intra-Company routes do not exceed 5 years within any 6-year period, including previous and potential permissions. Exceptions apply when calculating cumulative periods, considering ongoing or extended permissions.

metadata.section_title: Decision on an application as a Service Supplier

chunks.text:
### Decision on an application as a Service Supplier

SSU 12.1. If the decision maker is satisfied that all the suitability and eligibility requirements for a Service Supplier are met the application will be granted, otherwise the application will be refused.

SSU 12.2. If the application is refused the person can apply for an Administrative Review under Appendix AR: Administrative Review.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to Service Suppliers applying for endorsement. It requires the decision-maker to approve applications meeting all suitability and eligibility criteria; failure results in refusal, with applicants able to request an Administrative Review.
