metadata.section_title: Period and conditions of grant as a Service Supplier

chunks.text:
### Period and conditions of grant as a Service Supplier

1.   SSU 13.1. The grant will be subject to all the following conditions: 
    1.   (a) no access to public funds; and
    2.   (b) the only work permitted is: 
        1.   (i) the job for which the applicant is being sponsored; and
        2.   (ii) voluntary work; and

    3.   (c) study is permitted, subject to the ATAS condition in Appendix ATAS.
    4.   (d) DELETED

2.   SSU 13.2. If the application is for entry clearance, permission will be granted for a period which is the shortest of the following: 
    1.   (a) 14 days after the end date of the job detailed in the Certificate of Sponsorship; or
    2.   (b) the date at which the applicant will have had cumulative permission on the Global Business Mobility routes and Intra-Company routes totalling 5 years in any 6-year period; or
    3.   (c) the maximum single assignment period which is: 
        1.   (i) if the applicant is covered by a relevant commitment in the United Kingdom-European Union Trade and Cooperation Agreement and is a national of any Member State of the European Union or any other person included in the definition of “natural person of a Party” for the European Union in Article 512(k) of that agreement, 12 months; or
        2.   (ii) if the applicant is a Swiss national or permanent resident covered by a relevant commitment in the Temporary Agreement between the Swiss Confederation and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland on Services Mobility, 12 months; or
        3.   (iia) if the applicant is an Australian national or permanent resident covered by a relevant commitment in the Free Trade Agreement between the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and Australia, 12 months; or
        4.   (iib) if the applicant is covered by a relevant commitment in the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), and is a person included in the definition of “business person” under Article 12.1 of that agreement, 12 months, or;
        5.   (iii) in all other cases, 6 months.

3.   SSU 13.3. If the application is for permission to stay, the permission will be granted for a period which is the shortest of the following: 
    1.   (a) 14 days after the end date of the job detailed in the Certificate of Sponsorship; or
    2.   (b) the date at which the applicant will have had cumulative permission on the Global Business Mobility routes and Intra-Company routes totalling 5 years in any 6-year period; or
    3.   (c) the maximum single assignment period which is: 
        1.   (i) if the applicant is covered by a relevant commitment in the United Kingdom-European Union Trade and Cooperation Agreement and is a national of any Member State of the European Union or any other person included in the definition of “natural person of a Party” for the European Union in Article 512(k) of that agreement, the difference between the period the applicant has already spent in the UK since their last grant of permission as a Service Supplier and 12 months; or
        2.   (ii) if the applicant is a Swiss national or permanent resident covered by a relevant commitment in the Temporary Agreement between the Swiss Confederation and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland on Services Mobility, the difference between the period the applicant has already spent in the UK since their last grant of permission as a Service Supplier and 12 months; or
        3.   (iia) if the applicant is an Australian national or permanent resident covered by a relevant commitment in the Free Trade Agreement between the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and Australia, the difference between the period the applicant has already spent in the UK since their last grant of permission as a Service Supplier and 12 months; or
        4.   (iib) if the applicant is covered by a relevant commitment in the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), the difference between the period the applicant has already spent in the UK since their last grant of permission as a Service Supplier and 12 months; or
        5.   (iii) in all other cases, the difference between the period the applicant has already spent in the UK since their last grant of permission as a Service Supplier and 6 months.

SSU 13.4. If the applicant does not currently hold permission on the Global Business Mobility routes, any permission granted for the period between the date of decision and the start date of the job detailed in the Certificate of Sponsorship will be excluded from the cumulative permission for the purpose of determining the period of grant of permission under SSU 13.2. and SSU 13.3. (but not from the cumulative period in SSU 11.2.).
chunks.summary: This provision applies to Service Suppliers under the UK Global Business Mobility routes. It requires permission to be limited to specific work (sponsorship job and voluntary work), with no access to public funds, and subject to a maximum duration based on job end date, cumulative permitted time, or international agreements. Conditions vary depending on nationality and treaty commitments.

Section: Period and conditions of grant as a Service Supplier
Topic: financial

Summary: This provision applies to Service Suppliers under the UK Global Business Mobility routes. It requires permission to be limited to specific work (sponsorship job and voluntary work), with no access to public funds, and subject to a maximum duration based on job end date, cumulative permitted time, or international agreements. Conditions vary depending on nationality and treaty commitments.

### Period and conditions of grant as a Service Supplier

1.   SSU 13.1. The grant will be subject to all the following conditions: 
    1.   (a) no access to public funds; and
    2.   (b) the only work permitted is: 
        1.   (i) the job for which the applicant is being sponsored; and
        2.   (ii) voluntary work; and

    3.   (c) study is permitted, subject to the ATAS condition in Appendix ATAS.
    4.   (d) DELETED

2.   SSU 13.2. If the application is for entry clearance, permission will be granted for a period which is the shortest of the following: 
    1.   (a) 14 days after the end date of the job detailed in the Certificate of Sponsorship; or
    2.   (b) the date at which the applicant will have had cumulative permission on the Global Business Mobility routes and Intra-Company routes totalling 5 years in any 6-year period; or
    3.   (c) the maximum single assignment period which is: 
        1.   (i) if the applicant is covered by a relevant commitment in the United Kingdom-European Union Trade and Cooperation Agreement and is a national of any Member State of the European Union or any other person included in the definition of “natural person of a Party” for the European Union in Article 512(k) of that agreement, 12 months; or
        2.   (ii) if the applicant is a Swiss national or permanent resident covered by a relevant commitment in the Temporary Agreement between the Swiss Confederation and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland on Services Mobility, 12 months; or
        3.   (iia) if the applicant is an Australian national or permanent resident covered by a relevant commitment in the Free Trade Agreement between the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and Australia, 12 months; or
        4.   (iib) if the applicant is covered by a relevant commitment in the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), and is a person included in the definition of “business person” under Article 12.1 of that agreement, 12 months, or;
        5.   (iii) in all other cases, 6 months.

3.   SSU 13.3. If the application is for permission to stay, the permission will be granted for a period which is the shortest of the following: 
    1.   (a) 14 days after the end date of the job detailed in the Certificate of Sponsorship; or
    2.   (b) the date at which the applicant will have had cumulative permission on the Global Business Mobility routes and Intra-Company routes totalling 5 years in any 6-year period; or
    3.   (c) the maximum single assignment period which is: 
        1.   (i) if the applicant is covered by a relevant commitment in the United Kingdom-European Union Trade and Cooperation Agreement and is a national of any Member State of the European Union or any other person included in the definition of “natural person of a Party” for the European Union in Article 512(k) of that agreement, the difference between the period the applicant has already spent in the UK since their last grant of permission as a Service Supplier and 12 months; or
        2.   (ii) if the applicant is a Swiss national or permanent resident covered by a relevant commitment in the Temporary Agreement between the Swiss Confederation and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland on Services Mobility, the difference between the period the applicant has already spent in the UK since their last grant of permission as a Service Supplier and 12 months; or
        3.   (iia) if the applicant is an Australian national or permanent resident covered by a relevant commitment in the Free Trade Agreement between the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and Australia, the difference between the period the applicant has already spent in the UK since their last grant of permission as a Service Supplier and 12 months; or
        4.   (iib) if the applicant is covered by a relevant commitment in the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), the difference between the period the applicant has already spent in the UK since their last grant of permission as a Service Supplier and 12 months; or
        5.   (iii) in all other cases, the difference between the period the applicant has already spent in the UK since their last grant of permission as a Service Supplier and 6 months.

SSU 13.4. If the applicant does not currently hold permission on the Global Business Mobility routes, any permission granted for the period between the date of decision and the start date of the job detailed in the Certificate of Sponsorship will be excluded from the cumulative permission for the purpose of determining the period of grant of permission under SSU 13.2. and SSU 13.3. (but not from the cumulative period in SSU 11.2.).

metadata.section_title: Validity requirements for a partner or child of a Service Supplier

chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for a partner or child of a Service Supplier

SSU 14.1. A person applying for entry clearance or permission to stay as a partner or child of a Service Supplier must apply online on the gov.uk website on the specified form as follows:

| Applicant | Specified form |
| --- | --- |
| Applicants outside the UK | Dependant partner visa Dependant child visa |
| Applicants inside the UK | Dependant partner Dependant child |

1.   SSU 14.2. An application for entry clearance or permission to stay as a partner or child of a Service Supplier must meet all the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) any fee and Immigration Health Charge must have been paid; and
    2.   (b) the applicant must have provided biometrics when required; and
    3.   (c) the applicant must have provided either a passport or other travel document which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality; and
    4.   (d) the applicant must be applying as partner or child of a person who: 
        1.   (i) has made a valid application for entry clearance or permission to stay on the Global Business Mobility – Service Supplier route that has not been decided; or
        2.   (ii) has entry clearance or permission to stay on the Global Business Mobility – Service Supplier route.

SSU 14.3. A person applying as a partner must be aged 18 or over on the date of application.

1.   SSU 14.4. If applying for permission to stay, the applicant must be in the UK on the date of application.
2.   SSU 14.4ZA. If applying for permission to stay, the applicant must not have, or have last been granted, permission: 
    1.   (a) as a Visitor; or
    2.   (b) as a Short-term Student; or
    3.   (c) as a Parent of a Child Student; or
    4.   (d) as a Seasonal Worker; or
    5.   (e) as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household; or
    6.   (f) outside the Immigration Rules.

1.   SSU 14.4A. An applicant who is applying for permission to stay and has, or last had, permission as a Student, must fulfil one of the Conditions A or B below on the date of application: 
    1.   (a) Condition A: the applicant must have completed the course of study for which the Confirmation of Acceptance for Studies was assigned (or a course to which ST 27.3 of Appendix Student applies); or
    2.   (b) Condition B: the applicant must: 
        1.   (i) be studying a full-time course of study leading to the award of a PhD with a higher education provider which has a track record of compliance; and
        2.   (ii) have completed at least 24 months of study on that course.

SSU 14.5. An application which does not meet all the validity requirements for a partner or child of a Service Supplier may be rejected as invalid and not considered.
chunks.summary: Applicants who are partners or children of Service Suppliers must apply online, meet fee and biometric requirements, and provide identification. Partners must be at least 18 and both must have an active or pending Global Business Mobility – Service Supplier application; partners applying for permission to stay must be in the UK.

metadata.section_title: Suitability requirements for a partner or child of a Service Supplier

chunks.text:
### Suitability requirements for a partner or child of a Service Supplier

SSU 15.1. The applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.

1.   SSU 15.2. If applying for permission to stay the applicant must not be: 
    1.   (a) in breach of immigration laws, except that where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, that period of overstaying will be disregarded; or
    2.   (b) on immigration bail.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to partners or children of Service Suppliers seeking permission to stay under the UK Immigration Rules. Applicants must not breach immigration laws (except where overstaying is disregarded) or be on immigration bail to be considered suitable.

metadata.section_title: Entry requirement for a partner or child of a Service Supplier

chunks.text:
### Entry requirement for a partner or child of a Service Supplier

SSU 16.1. A person seeking to come to the UK as a partner or child must apply for and obtain entry clearance as a partner or child of a Service Supplier before they arrive in the UK.

SSU 16.2. A person applying for entry clearance as the partner or child of a Service Supplier must, if Appendix Tuberculosis applies, provide a valid medical certificate confirming that they have undergone screening for active pulmonary tuberculosis and that this tuberculosis is not present in them.
chunks.summary: Partners and children of Service Suppliers must apply for and obtain entry clearance before arriving in the UK. If applicable under Appendix Tuberculosis, they must also submit a valid medical certificate confirming they do not have active pulmonary tuberculosis.

    1.   (a) P has permission on the Global Business Mobility – Service Supplier route; or
    2.   (b) P is, at the same time, applying for (and is granted) entry clearance or permission on the Global Business Mobility – Service Supplier route.

SSU 17.2. The requirements of Appendix Relationship with Partner must be met. SSU 17.3. DELETED

SSU 17.4. DELETED

### Requirements for a dependent child of a Service Supplier

    1.   (a) relationship requirement: entry clearance and permission to stay; and
    2.   (b) care requirement; and
    3.   (c) age and independent life requirement.

metadata.section_title: Financial requirement for a partner or child of a Service Supplier

chunks.text:
### Financial requirement for a partner or child of a Service Supplier

SSU 21.1. If the applicant is applying for permission to stay and has been living in the UK with permission for 12 months or longer on the date of application, they will meet the financial requirement and do not need to show funds.

1.   SSU 21.2. If the applicant is applying for entry clearance, or is applying for permission to stay and has not been in the UK for 12 months on the date of application, either: 
    1.   (a) funds of at least the amount required in SSU 21.3 must be held collectively by one or more of the following: 
        1.   (i) the applicant; and
        2.   (ii) the Service Supplier (P); and
        3.   (iii) if the applicant is applying as a child, their parent who is lawfully present in the UK or being granted entry clearance, or permission to stay, at the same time as the applicant; or

    2.   (b) the sponsor of P must confirm on the Certificate of Sponsorship that they will, if necessary, maintain and accommodate the partner and/or any child as well as P, up to the end of the first month of each of their permission, up to at least the amounts in SSU 21.3.

2.   SSU 21.3. The required funds are: 
    1.   (a) £285 for a partner in the UK or applying for entry clearance; and
    2.   (b) £315 for the first child in the UK or applying for entry clearance; and
    3.   (c) £200 for any other child in the UK or applying for entry clearance.

SSU 21.4. If SSU 21.2.(a) applies, the funds held must be held in addition to any funds required for the Service Supplier to meet the financial requirement and the funds required for any dependants in the UK or applying at the same time.

SSU 21.5. If SSU 21.2.(a) applies, the funds must have been held for a 28-day period and as specified in Appendix Finance.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to partners and children of Service Suppliers seeking permission to stay or entry clearance. Applicants who have lived in the UK for 12 months or more do not need to show funds; otherwise, they must meet specified financial thresholds (£285 for a partner, £315 for the first child, and £200 for additional children) or have sponsor confirmation. Critical conditions include age and residency status, with exceptions for long-term residents.

metadata.section_title: Decision on an application as a partner or child of a Service Supplier

chunks.text:
### Decision on an application as a partner or child of a Service Supplier

SSU 22.1. If the decision maker is satisfied that all the suitability and eligibility requirements are met for a partner or child of a Service Supplier the application will be granted, otherwise the application will be refused.

SSU 22.2. If the application is refused the person can apply for an Administrative Review under Appendix AR: Administrative Review.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to partners or children of Service Suppliers seeking entry. If all suitability and eligibility criteria are met, the application will be granted; otherwise, it will be refused. Refused applicants may request an Administrative Review.

### Decision on an application as a partner or child of a Service Supplier

SSU 22.1. If the decision maker is satisfied that all the suitability and eligibility requirements are met for a partner or child of a Service Supplier the application will be granted, otherwise the application will be refused.

SSU 22.2. If the application is refused the person can apply for an Administrative Review under Appendix AR: Administrative Review.

metadata.section_title: Period and conditions of grant for a partner or child of a Service Supplier

chunks.text:
### Period and conditions of grant for a partner or child of a Service Supplier

SSU 23.1. A partner will be granted permission which ends on the same date as the person (P) who is their partner and has permission as a Service Supplier.

SSU 23.2. A child will be granted permission which ends on the same date as whichever of their parents’ permission ends first.

1.   SSU 23.3. The grant will be subject to all the following conditions: 
    1.   (a) no access to public funds; and
    2.   (b) work (including self-employment and voluntary work) permitted; except for employment as a professional sportsperson (including as a sports coach); and
    3.   (c) study is permitted, subject to the ATAS condition in Appendix ATAS.
    4.   (d) DELETED

The Global Business Mobility – Secondment Worker route is for overseas workers who are undertaking temporary work assignments in the UK, where the worker is being seconded to the UK as part of a high value contract or investment by their employer overseas.

A dependent partner and dependent children can apply to come to the UK on this route.

The Global Business Mobility – Secondment Worker route is not a route to settlement.
chunks.summary: Dependent partners and children of Service Suppliers are granted permissions that end with the main applicant’s permission, subject to conditions: no access to public funds, permitted work (excluding professional sports), and study (with ATAS). These dependents cannot settle in the UK and must meet these criteria throughout their stay.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Global Business Mobility routes
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Global Business Mobility routes
metadata.section_title: Validity requirements for a Global Business Mobility - Secondment Worker (“Secondment Worker”)

chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for a Global Business Mobility - Secondment Worker (“Secondment Worker”)

1.   SEC 1.1. A person applying for entry clearance or permission to stay as a Secondment Worker must apply online on the gov.uk website on the specified form as follows: 
    1.   (a) for applicants outside the UK, form “Global Business Mobility visa”; or
    2.   (b) for applicants inside the UK, form “Global Business Mobility”.

2.   SEC 1.2. An application for entry clearance or permission to stay as a Secondment Worker must meet all the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) any fee and Immigration Health Charge must have been paid; and
    2.   (b) the applicant must have provided biometrics when required; and
    3.   (c) the applicant must have provided a passport or other travel document which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality; and
    4.   (d) the applicant must have a Certificate of Sponsorship that was issued to them by their sponsor no more than 3 months before the date of application.

SEC 1.3. The applicant must be aged 18 or over on the date of application.

SEC 1.4. An applicant applying for entry clearance or permission to stay as a Secondment Worker who has received an award from a Government or international scholarship agency in the 12 months before the date of application which covers both fees and living costs for study in the UK, must have provided written consent to the application from that Government or agency.

1.   SEC 1.5. If applying for permission to stay, the applicant must be in the UK on the date of application.
2.   SEC 1.5ZA. If applying for permission to stay, the applicant must not have, or have last been granted, permission: 
    1.   (a) as a Visitor; or
    2.   (b) as a Short-term Student; or
    3.   (c) as a Parent of a Child Student; or
    4.   (d) as a Seasonal Worker; or
    5.   (e) as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household; or
    6.   (f) outside the Immigration Rules.

1.   SEC 1.5A. An applicant who is applying for permission to stay and has, or last had, permission as a Student, must fulfil one of the Conditions A, B or C below on the date of application: 
    1.   (a) Condition A: the applicant must have completed the course of study for which the Confirmation of Acceptance for Studies was assigned (or a course to which ST 27.3 of Appendix Student applies); or
    2.   (b) Condition B: 
        1.   (i) the applicant must be studying a full-time course of study at degree level or above with a higher education provider which has a track record of compliance; and
        2.   (ii) the Certificate of Sponsorship in SEC 1.2(d) must have a start date no earlier than the course completion date; or

    3.   (c) Condition C: 
        1.   (i) the applicant must be studying a full-time course of study leading to the award of a PhD with a higher education provider which has a track record of compliance; and
        2.   (ii) the Certificate of Sponsorship in SEC 1.2(d) must have a start date no earlier than 24 months after the start date of that course.

SEC 1.6. An application which does not meet all the validity requirements for a Secondment Worker may be rejected as invalid and not considered.
chunks.summary: Applicants for a Secondment Worker visa must apply online, pay fees, provide biometrics, a valid passport, and a recently issued Certificate of Sponsorship. They must be at least 18 and, if funded by a government scholarship in the past year covering costs, must obtain written consent from the sponsor.

metadata.section_title: Suitability requirements for a Secondment Worker

chunks.text:
### Suitability requirements for a Secondment Worker

SEC 2.1. The applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.

1.   SEC 2.2. If applying for permission to stay the applicant must not be: 
    1.   (a) in breach of immigration laws, except that where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, that period of overstaying will be disregarded; or
    2.   (b) on immigration bail.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to Secondment Workers. They must be free from immigration law breaches and not be on bail to be considered suitable; overstaying may be disregarded under specific exceptions.

metadata.section_title: Eligibility requirements for a Secondment Worker

chunks.text: ### Eligibility requirements for a Secondment Worker
chunks.summary: This section applies to Secondment Workers seeking entry under the Global Business Mobility routes. Applicants must be employed by an overseas company and temporarily seconded to the UK, meeting specific employment and duration criteria, with exceptions for certain durations and circumstances.

metadata.section_title: Entry requirements for a Secondment Worker

chunks.text:
### Entry requirements for a Secondment Worker

SEC 3.1. A person seeking to come to the UK as a Secondment Worker must apply for and obtain entry clearance as a Secondment Worker before their arrival in the UK.

SEC 3.2. A person applying for entry clearance as a Secondment Worker must, if Appendix Tuberculosis applies, provide a valid medical certificate confirming that they have undergone screening for active pulmonary tuberculosis and that this tuberculosis is not present in them.
chunks.summary: Secondment Workers seeking UK entry must obtain entry clearance beforehand and, if applicable under Appendix Tuberculosis, provide a medical certificate confirming TB screening; no exceptions are specified.

metadata.section_title: Points requirement for a Secondment Worker

chunks.text:
### Points requirement for a Secondment Worker

SEC 4.1. The applicant must be awarded all 40 points in the table below:

| Points requirements | Relevant rules | Points |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Sponsorship | SEC 5.1. to SEC 5.7. | 20 |
| Job at an appropriate skill level | SEC 6.1. to SEC 6.6. | 20 |

1.   SEC 5.1. The applicant must have a valid Certificate of Sponsorship for the job they are planning to do, which to be valid must: 
    1.   (a) confirm the applicant’s name, that they are being sponsored as a Secondment Worker, and details of the job the sponsor is offering them; and
    2.   (b) include a start date for the job, stated by the sponsor, which must be no more than 3 months after the date of application; and
    3.   (c) not have been used in a previous application which was either granted or refused (but can have been used in a previous application which was rejected as invalid, made void or withdrawn); and
    4.   (d) not have been withdrawn by the sponsor or cancelled by the Home Office; and
    5.   (e) DELETED
    6.   (f) confirm whether or not the Academic Technology Approval Scheme (ATAS) requirement in Appendix ATAS applies; and
    7.   (g) confirm on which of the sponsor’s contracts registered with the Home Office the applicant will work.

SEC 5.2. The sponsor must be authorised by the Home Office to sponsor a Secondment Worker.

SEC 5.3. The sponsor must be listed as A-rated on the Home Office’s register of licensed sponsors, unless the applicant was last granted permission as a Secondment Worker and is applying to continue working for the same sponsor as in their last permission.

SEC 5.4. The sponsor must have a contract with an overseas business, where that contract has been registered with the Home Office, and on which an applicant as a Secondment Worker will work.

1.   SEC 5.5. The decision maker must not have reasonable grounds to believe the job the applicant is being sponsored to do: 
    1.   (a) does not exist; or
    2.   (b) is a sham; or
    3.   (c) has been created mainly so the applicant can apply for entry clearance or permission to stay.

2.   SEC 5.6. The decision maker must not have reasonable grounds to believe the job the applicant is being sponsored to do amounts to: 
    1.   (a) the hire of the applicant to a third party who is not the sponsor to fill a position with that party, whether temporary or permanent; or
    2.   (b) contract work to undertake an ongoing routine role or to provide an ongoing routine service for a third party who is not the sponsor, regardless of the nature or length of any arrangement between the sponsor and the third party.

3.   SEC 5.6A. The decision maker must not have reasonable grounds to believe the job the applicant is being sponsored to do does not comply with the National Minimum Wage Regulations or the Working Time Regulations.

SEC 5.7. If the requirements in SEC 5.1. to SEC 5.6. are met, the applicant will be awarded 20 points for sponsorship.
chunks.summary: Secondment Workers must score 40 points by securing 20 points for sponsorship—via a valid Certificate of Sponsorship—and 20 points for working at an appropriate skill level. The sponsorship must be valid, linked to an eligible contract, and the sponsor must be an A-rated, licensed sponsor. Exceptions apply if the sponsor's license has been revoked or the sponsorship is invalid.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Global Business Mobility routes
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Global Business Mobility routes
metadata.section_title: Points for job at appropriate skill level for a Secondment Worker

chunks.text:
### Points for job at appropriate skill level for a Secondment Worker

SEC 6.1. The applicant must be sponsored for a job in a SOC 2020 occupation code listed in Table 2 or Table 3 of Appendix Skilled Occupations.

SEC 6.1A. If the date of application is before 4 April 2030, the applicant was granted permission as a Secondment Worker under the Rules in place before 4 April 2024, and they have had continuous permission as a Secondment Worker since then (except that where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, that period of overstaying will be disregarded), they may be sponsored for a job in a SOC 2020 occupation code listed in Table 2b of Appendix Skilled Occupations.

SEC 6.2. The sponsor must choose an appropriate SOC 2020 occupation code, and the decision maker must not have reasonable grounds to believe the sponsor has chosen a less appropriate SOC 2020 occupation code due to the most appropriate SOC 2020 occupation code not being eligible under the Global Business Mobility routes.

1.   SEC 6.3. To support the assessment in SEC 6.2, the decision maker may, in particular, consider: 
    1.   (a) whether the sponsor has shown a genuine need for the job as described; and
    2.   (b) whether the applicant has the appropriate skills, qualifications and experience needed to do the job as described; and
    3.   (c) the sponsor’s history of compliance with the immigration system including, but not limited to, paying its sponsored workers appropriately; and
    4.   (d) any additional information from the sponsor.

SEC 6.4. If the ATAS requirement in Appendix ATAS applies, the applicant must provide a valid ATAS certificate.

SEC 6.5. If the requirements in SEC 6.1. to SEC 6.4. are met, the applicant will be awarded 20 points for a job at the appropriate skill level, subject to SEC 6.6.

SEC 6.6. No points will be awarded for a job at the appropriate skill level if the applicant is not also being awarded 20 points for sponsorship under SEC 5.7.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to Secondment Workers under UK Immigration Rules, requiring sponsors to assign an appropriate SOC 2020 occupation code for the job. Applicants must be sponsored for jobs listed in specified tables, with certain transitional provisions for those, granted prior permissions, and continuous permission holders. Decision-makers assess the genuine need, applicant’s skills, and sponsor compliance, ensuring suitable occupation coding without unreasonable grounds for misclassification.

metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Global Business Mobility routes
metadata.section_title: Overseas Work requirement for a Secondment Worker

chunks.text:
### Overseas Work requirement for a Secondment Worker

1.   SEC 7.1 The applicant must meet the overseas work requirement at SEC 7.2. unless the applicant: 
    1.   (a) is applying for permission to stay; and
    2.   (b) has, or last had, permission as a Secondment Worker; and
    3.   (c) is applying to continue working for the same sponsor as in their last permission.

2.   SEC 7.2 The overseas requirement will be met where the applicant: 
    1.   (a) is currently working for an overseas business that has a contract with the sponsor that has been registered with the Home Office by the sponsor; and
    2.   (b) has worked outside the UK for that overseas business for a cumulative period of at least 12 months.

3.   SEC 7.3. In SEC 7.2.(b) the 12 months’ work outside the UK can have been accumulated over any period provided that: 
    1.   (a) the applicant was continuously working for the overseas businesses in SEC 7.2.(a), whether in or out of the UK, from the start of the 12 months to the date of application; and
    2.   (b) any breaks in the continuous work in SEC 7.3.(a) were only for the following reasons: 
        1.   (i) statutory maternity, paternity, parental, or shared parental leave; or
        2.   (ii) statutory adoption leave; or
        3.   (iii) sick leave; or
        4.   (iv) assisting with a national or international humanitarian or environmental crisis, with the agreement of the overseas business in SEC 7.2.(a); or
        5.   (v) taking part in legally organised industrial action; or
        6.   (vi) jury service; or
        7.   (vii) attending court as a witness.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to Secondment Workers seeking UK permission to stay or continue working for the same sponsor. It requires the applicant to have worked at least 12 months outside the UK for an overseas business linked to their sponsor, with permissible breaks for specific statutory or humanitarian reasons. Exceptions apply if applying to remain and already possess previous Secondment Worker permission.

metadata.section_title: Genuineness requirement for a Secondment Worker

chunks.text:
### Genuineness requirement for a Secondment Worker

1.   SEC 7A.1. The applicant must: 
    1.   (a) genuinely intend, and be able, to undertake the role for which they are being sponsored; and
    2.   (b) not intend to undertake employment other than in the role for which they are being sponsored, or as otherwise permitted by SEC 11.1.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to Secondment Workers under the Global Business Mobility routes. They must genuinely intend and be capable of performing the sponsored role and not seek employment outside that role unless permitted, ensuring the genuineness of their employment.

Section: Genuineness requirement for a Secondment Worker
Topic: eligibility

Summary: This provision applies to Secondment Workers under the Global Business Mobility routes. They must genuinely intend and be capable of performing the sponsored role and not seek employment outside that role unless permitted, ensuring the genuineness of their employment.

### Genuineness requirement for a Secondment Worker

1.   SEC 7A.1. The applicant must: 
    1.   (a) genuinely intend, and be able, to undertake the role for which they are being sponsored; and
    2.   (b) not intend to undertake employment other than in the role for which they are being sponsored, or as otherwise permitted by SEC 11.1.

metadata.source: Immigration Rules Appendix Global Business Mobility routes
metadata.part: Immigration Rules Appendix Global Business Mobility routes
metadata.section_title: Financial requirement for a Secondment Worker

chunks.text:
### Financial requirement for a Secondment Worker

SEC 8.1. If the applicant is applying for permission to stay and has been living in the UK with permission for 12 months or longer on the date of application, they will meet the financial requirement and do not need to show funds.

1.   SEC 8.2. If the applicant is applying for entry clearance or has been living in the UK for less than 12 months on the date of application either: 
    1.   (a) the applicant must have funds of at least £1,270; or
    2.   (b) the applicant’s A-rated sponsor must confirm on the Certificate of Sponsorship that they will, if it is necessary, maintain and accommodate the applicant up to the end of the first month of their employment to an amount of at least £1,270.

SEC 8.3. If SEC 8.2.(a) applies, the applicant must show that they have held the required level of funds for a 28-day period and as set out in Appendix Finance.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to Secondment Workers. If the applicant has lived in the UK for 12 months or more, they meet the financial requirement automatically; if less, they must have at least £1,270 in funds or have their sponsor confirm maintenance. Applicants with less than 12 months' residence must demonstrate funds for 28 days unless the sponsor guarantees support.

metadata.section_title: Maximum length of assignments requirement for a Secondment Worker

chunks.text:
### Maximum length of assignments requirement for a Secondment Worker

SEC 9.1. The grant of permission must not lead to the applicant being granted cumulative periods of permission on the Global Business Mobility routes and the Intra-Company routes totalling more than 5 years in any 6-year period.

1.   SEC 9.2. When calculating the cumulative periods of permission referred to in SEC 9.1. and SEC 11.2.(d), the decision maker will include the following: 
    1.   (a) all previous periods of permission on the Global Business Mobility routes; and
    2.   (b) all previous periods of permission on the Intra-Company routes; and
    3.   (c) if the applicant does not currently hold permission on a Global Business Mobility route, any permission they could be granted under this application, beginning on the start date of the job stated on the Certificate of Sponsorship; and
    4.   (d) if the applicant is applying for permission to stay and has or last had permission on the Global Business Mobility routes, any permission they could be granted under this application, beginning on the date of decision; and
    5.   (e) any period of permission on the Global Business Mobility routes and the Intra-Company routes extended under section 3C of the Immigration Act 1971.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to Secondment Workers under UK Global Business Mobility routes. It requires that their total permission periods within these routes and Intra-Company routes do not exceed 5 years in any 6-year period, including previous and potential permissions. The calculation accounts for all relevant permissions and extensions.

metadata.section_title: Decision on an application as a Secondment Worker

chunks.text:
### Decision on an application as a Secondment Worker

SEC 10.1. If the decision maker is satisfied that all the suitability and eligibility requirements for a Secondment Worker on the Global Business Mobility route are met the application will be granted, otherwise the application will be refused.

SEC 10.2. If the application is refused the person can apply for an Administrative Review under Appendix AR: Administrative Review.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to Secondment Workers under the Global Business Mobility route. It requires that applicants meet all suitability and eligibility criteria for a decision to be granted; failure to do so results in refusal, with a right to Administrative Review.

metadata.section_title: Period and conditions of grant as a Secondment Worker

chunks.text:
### Period and conditions of grant as a Secondment Worker

1.   SEC 11.1. The grant will be subject to all the following conditions: 
    1.   (a) no access to public funds; and
    2.   (b) the only work permitted is: 
        1.   (i) the job for which the applicant is being sponsored; and
        2.   (ii) voluntary work; and
        3.   (iii) working out a contractual notice period, where the applicant was lawfully working in that job in the UK on the date of application; and

    3.   (c) study is permitted, subject to the ATAS condition in Appendix ATAS.
    4.   (d) DELETED

2.   SEC 11.2. Permission will be granted for a period which is the shortest of the following: 
    1.   (a) 1 year after the start date of the job detailed in the Certificate of Sponsorship; or
    2.   (b) 14 days after the end date of the job detailed in the Certificate of Sponsorship; or
    3.   (c) the date at which the applicant will have had a continuous permission as a Secondment Worker totalling 2 years.
    4.   (d) the date at which the applicant will have had cumulative permission on the Global Business Mobility routes and Intra-Company routes totalling 5 years in any 6-year period.

SEC 11.3. If the applicant does not currently hold permission on the Global Business Mobility routes, any permission granted for the period between the date of decision and the start date of the job detailed in the Certificate of Sponsorship will be excluded from the cumulative permission for the purpose of determining the period of grant of permission under SEC 11.2. (but not from the cumulative period in SEC 9.2.).
chunks.summary: This provision applies to Secondment Workers under UK Immigration Rules. It requires permission for a maximum of 2 years or until 5 years' cumulative Global Business Mobility permissions, permitting work only for sponsored employment, voluntary work, or contractual notice periods, with no access to public funds and possible study under ATAS. Permissions exclude any granted before employment start date if the applicant is new to the route.

metadata.section_title: Validity requirements for a partner or child of a Secondment Worker

chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for a partner or child of a Secondment Worker

SEC 12.1. A person applying for entry clearance or permission to stay as a partner or child of a Secondment Worker must apply online on the gov.uk website on the specified form as follows:

| Applicant | Specified form |
| --- | --- |
| Applicants outside the UK | Dependant partner visa Dependant child visa |
| Applicants inside the UK | Dependant partner Dependant child |

1.   SEC 12.2. An application for entry clearance or permission to stay as a partner or child of a Secondment Worker must meet all the following requirements:
2.   (a) any fee and Immigration Health Charge must have been paid; and
3.   (b) the applicant must have provided biometrics when required; and
4.   (c) the applicant must have provided either a passport or other travel document which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality; and
5.   (d) the applicant must be applying as partner or child of a person who: 
    1.   (i) has made a valid application for entry clearance or permission to stay on the Global Business Mobility – Secondment Worker route that has not been decided; or
    2.   (ii) has entry clearance or permission to stay on the Global Business Mobility – Secondment Worker route.

SEC 12.3. A person applying as a partner must be aged 18 or over on the date of application.

1.   SEC 12.4. If applying for permission to stay, the applicant must be in the UK on the date of application.
2.   SEC 12.4ZA. If applying for permission to stay, the applicant must not have, or have last been granted, permission: 
    1.   (a) as a Visitor; or
    2.   (b) as a Short-term Student; or
    3.   (c) as a Parent of a Child Student; or
    4.   (d) as a Seasonal Worker; or
    5.   (e) as a Domestic Worker in a Private Household; or
    6.   (f) outside the Immigration Rules.

1.   SEC 12.4A. An applicant who is applying for permission to stay and has, or last had, permission as a Student, must fulfil one of the Conditions A or B below on the date of application: 
    1.   (a) Condition A: the applicant must have completed the course of study for which the Confirmation of Acceptance for Studies was assigned (or a course to which ST 27.3 of Appendix Student applies); or
    2.   (b) Condition B: the applicant must: 
        1.   (i) be studying a full-time course of study leading to the award of a PhD with a higher education provider which has a track record of compliance; and
        2.   (ii) have completed at least 24 months of study on that course.

SEC 12.5. An application which does not meet all the validity requirements for a partner or child of a Secondment Worker may be rejected as invalid and not considered.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to partners and children of Secondment Workers applying for entry clearance or permission to stay. Applicants must submit online forms, pay fees, provide biometrics and travel documents, and be connected to a valid Secondment Worker route. Key conditions include age (18+ for partners) and being physically present in the UK when applying for permission to stay.

metadata.section_title: Suitability requirements for a partner or child of a Secondment Worker

chunks.text:
### Suitability requirements for a partner or child of a Secondment Worker

SEC 13.1. The applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.

1.   SEC 13.2. If applying for permission to stay the applicant must not be: 
    1.   (a) in breach of immigration laws, except that where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, that period of overstaying will be disregarded; or
    2.   (b) on immigration bail.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to partners or children of Secondment Workers seeking permission to stay. They must be suitable under immigration law, not in breach of immigration conditions (with some exceptions for overstaying) or on immigration bail.

metadata.section_title: Entry requirement for a partner or child of a Secondment Worker

chunks.text:
### Entry requirement for a partner or child of a Secondment Worker

SEC 14.1. A person seeking to come to the UK as a partner or child must apply for and obtain entry clearance as a partner or child of a Secondment Worker before they arrive in the UK.

SEC 14.2. A person applying for entry clearance as the partner or child of a Secondment Worker must, if Appendix Tuberculosis applies, provide a valid medical certificate confirming that they have undergone screening for active pulmonary tuberculosis and that this tuberculosis is not present in them.
chunks.summary: Partners or children of Secondment Workers must obtain prior entry clearance as their dependents. They must also provide a TB medical certificate if Appendix Tuberculosis applies; no specific exceptions listed.

### Relationship requirement for a partner of a Secondment Worker

1.   SEC 15.1. The applicant must be the partner of a person (P) where one of the following applies: 
    1.   (a) P has permission on the Global Business Mobility – Secondment Worker route; or
    2.   (b) P is, at the same time, applying for (and is granted) entry clearance or permission on the Global Business Mobility – Secondment Worker route.

SEC 15.2. The requirements of Appendix Relationship with Partner must be met.

SEC 15.3. DELETED

SEC 15.4. DELETED

No exceptions are specified beyond these conditions.

    3.   (c) age and independent life requirement.

Summary: Dependent children of Secondment Workers must meet relationship, care, and age/independent living requirements, including entry clearance and permission to stay, as specified in Appendix Children, with conditions applying to their dependency status.

### Requirements for a dependent child of a Secondment Worker

1.   SEC 18A.1. The applicant must meet the following requirements for a dependent child in Appendix Children: 
    1.   (a) relationship requirement: entry clearance and permission to stay; and
    2.   (b) care requirement; and
    3.   (c) age and independent life requirement.

metadata.section_title: Financial requirement for a partner or child of a Secondment Worker

chunks.text:
### Financial requirement for a partner or child of a Secondment Worker

SEC 19.1. If the applicant is applying for permission to stay and has been living in the UK with permission for 12 months or longer on the date of application, they will meet the financial requirement and do not need to show funds.

1.   SEC 19.2. If the applicant is applying for entry clearance, or is applying for permission to stay and has not been in the UK for 12 months on the date of application, either: 
    1.   (a) funds of at least the amount required in SEC 19.3 must be held collectively by one or more of the following: 
        1.   (i) the applicant; and
        2.   (ii) the Secondment Worker (P); and
        3.   (iii) if the applicant is applying as a child, their parent who is lawfully present in the UK or being granted entry clearance, or permission to stay, at the same time; or

    2.   (b) the sponsor of P must confirm on the Certificate of Sponsorship that they will, if necessary, maintain and accommodate the partner and/or any child as well as P, up to the end of the first month of each of their permission, up to at least the amounts in SEC 19.3.

2.   SEC 19.3. The required funds are: 
    1.   (a) £285 for a partner in the UK or applying for entry clearance; and
    2.   (b) £315 for the first child in the UK or applying for entry clearance; and
    3.   (c) £200 for any other child in the UK or applying for entry clearance.

SEC 19.4. If SEC 19.2.(a) applies, the funds held must be held in addition to any funds required for the Secondment Worker to meet the financial requirement and the funds required for any dependants in the UK or applying at the same time.

SEC 19.5. If SEC 19.2.(a) applies, the funds must have been held for a 28-day period and as specified in Appendix Finance.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to partners and children of Secondment Workers seeking permission to stay or entry clearance. Applicants who have lived in the UK for 12 months or more do not need to show financial funds, while those with less than 12 months must demonstrate specific financial thresholds (£285 for a partner, £315 for the first child, and £200 for additional children) held collectively or assured by the sponsor.

metadata.section_title: Decision on an application as a partner and child of a Secondment Worker

chunks.text:
### Decision on an application as a partner and child of a Secondment Worker

SEC 20.1. If the decision maker is satisfied that all the suitability and eligibility requirements are met for a partner or child of a Secondment Worker the application will be granted, otherwise the application will be refused.

SEC 20.2. If the application is refused the person can apply for an Administrative Review under Appendix AR: Administrative Review.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to partners and children of Secondment Workers applying for immigration; their application must meet suitability and eligibility criteria. If met, the application is granted; if not, it is refused, with a right to an Administrative Review.

metadata.section_title: Period and conditions of grant for a partner or child of a Secondment Worker

chunks.text:
### Period and conditions of grant for a partner or child of a Secondment Worker

SEC 21.1. A partner will be granted permission which ends on the same date as the person (P) who is their partner and has permission as a Secondment Worker.

SEC 21.2. A child will be granted permission which ends on the same date as whichever of their parents’ permission ends first.

1.   SEC 21.3. The grant will be subject to all the following conditions: 
    1.   (a) no access to public funds; and
    2.   (b) work (including self-employment and voluntary work) permitted; except for employment as a professional sportsperson (including as a sports coach); and
    3.   (c) study is permitted, subject to the ATAS condition in Appendix ATAS.
    4.   (d) DELETED
chunks.summary: Partners and children of Secondment Workers receive permission ending with the worker's or their parent's permission, respectively, subject to conditions including no public funds, permitted work (excluding professional sports), and study with ATAS approval.
